10003.description: Tutor the future of our city! Volunteer tutors are needed to work with the remarkable community at Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School (MCNDHS)! MCNDHS is a public school whose students are between 17 and 21 years old, many of whom are recent immigrants and all of whom are working toward their NY State HS Regents diploma. Tutors are needed for all subjects, including: English (all levels, from basic conversation to advanced grammar/writing) Math (all levels, especially Algebra) Science (especially Biology and Earth Science) History (Global and U.S.) Tutors are needed Monday through Friday, from 10am to 8pm. Please contact Daniel Bloch at (212) 353-2010 x160, or volunteer@cdi-ny.org if you're interested.
10003.title: Volunteer Tutors

10003.description: The BRC Palace Employment program is a 110-bed men’s shelter designed for those in need of job training and employment. Located in the former Palace Hotel on the Bowery, the program-oriented shelter provides temporary housing for a period of six to nine months. During this time, clients are guided through a structured continuum of treatment and training designed to give them the skills they need to address any substance abuse and/or health issues and to find and maintain permanent employment and housing. In the same building is the Bowery Safe Haven, which houses clients that are chronically street homeless individuals who have not been successful in other environments, but are willing to leave the streets and work on securing permanent housing. As a low-demand program, participants are not required to maintain sobriety and do not have any curfew; the one requirement upon entering is that they actively work toward obtaining housing. If you love old school board games, chess, backgammon, charades, or perhaps new school is more your speed with Heads Up or any other fun activity, then this opportunity is perfect for you. We would love to have a couple of volunteers that can host a weekly night of fun and relaxation while playing a few games & sharing some laughs in the process. We can provide the games, you just bring the fun! We are rather flexible with the day of the week, so if this is of interest, just let me know what night(s) work for you. Get in touch! PLEASE NOTE: In order to insure the integrity of the BRC volunteer program, as well as the well being of the clients we service, all interested parties must complete a New Volunteer Registration form and attend an orientation, prior to receiving an assignment. Apologies, but we are unable to accept walk-ins.
10003.title: Do You Love Game Night?

10003.description: The BRC Palace Employment program is a 110-bed men’s shelter designed for those in need of job training and employment. Located in the former Palace Hotel on the Bowery, the program-oriented shelter provides temporary housing for a period of six to nine months. Through art, our clients are able to express themselves in ways that they may not know themselves, and this would be a fantastic vehicle with which we can help them in their ongoing services. 10003.title: Run a Weekly Arts & Crafts Group

10003.description: Located on the Lower East Side on Pitt Street, Los Vecinos Apartments is a co-ed 35 room permanent housing facility for formerly homeless men and women suffering from mental illness, substance abuse and HIV/AIDS. While providing permanent housing for its tenants, Los Vecinos also offers a variety of services aimed at helping clients stabilize their health, maintain their independence and build a community of support among peers. These services include case management, referrals to medical facilities and assistance managing health conditions, medication monitoring, health education, psychiatric management, entitlement support and money management, recreational activities, assistance with activities of daily living and free meals. Why not join the volunteer team and make a difference? So you think collages are cool? Knitting is nice? Painting is positive? You look at art materials and all you see is potential? If this is your thing, we can sure use your talents! We currently run a mid-afternoon arts & crafts group every other Sunday and would love a volunteer with fresh and new ideas to join the team. You bring the ideas, we’ll provide the supplies! PLEASE NOTE: In order to insure the integrity of the BRC volunteer program, as well as the well being of the clients we service, all interested parties must complete a New Volunteer Registration form and attend an orientation, prior to receiving an assignment. Apologies, but we are unable to accept walk-ins.
10003.title: Calling All Crafters and Artistic Folks!

10003.description: Located on the Lower East Side on Pitt Street, Los Vecinos Apartments is a co-ed 35 room permanent housing facility for formerly homeless men and women suffering from mental illness, substance abuse and HIV/AIDS. These services include case management, referrals to medical facilities and assistance managing health conditions, medication monitoring, health education, psychiatric management, entitlement support and money management, recreational activities, assistance with activities of daily living and free meals. Why not join the volunteer team and make a difference? Are you a certified yoga instructor? Would you like to share your knowledge and gain some good karma in the process? If so, perhaps you’d consider hosting a weekly low level yoga class with a small group of residents at Los Vecinos. As you already know, yoga is an excellent means to improve flexibility & gain muscle strength, as well as increase self-esteem and bring inner peace. We can all use a bit more of this in our lives; why not share your abilities with our residents? If this is of interest, just get in touch with your availability and we will get this going! Apologies, but we are unable to accept walk-ins.
10003.title: Host a Weekly "Smoothie Group"!

10003.description: Located on the Lower East Side on Pitt Street, BRC Los Vecinos Apartments is a co-ed 35 room permanent housing facility for formerly homeless men and women suffering from mental illness, substance abuse and HIV/AIDS. While providing permanent housing for its tenants, Los Vecinos also offers a variety of services aimed at helping clients stabilize their health, maintain their independence and build a community of support among peers. These services include case management, referrals to medical facilities and assistance managing health conditions, medication monitoring, health education, psychiatric management, entitlement support and money management, recreational activities, assistance with activities of daily living and free meals. Why not join the volunteer team and make a difference? Bring Some Enthusiasm and Good Cheer and Help Serve at a Client Accomplishment Dinner - In order to recognize our residents’ accomplishments, progress & achievements in the prior month, the staff of Los Vecinos Apartments enjoy hosting a monthly special dinner. It’s a fun early evening of peer support, shared laughs and warm stories. We would love if we could identify two to three supportive, smiling, eager volunteers that can assist with set-up, decorating, service and post-dinner clean-up. Of course, you’re always welcome to enjoy the festivities and have a meal with our clients. This is always on the last Tuesday of every month and volunteers are needed from 4pm to 5pm. PLEASE NOTE: In order to insure the integrity of the BRC volunteer program, as well as the well being of the clients we service, all interested parties must complete a New Volunteer Registration form ( Click here for form) and attend an orientation, prior to receiving an assignment. Apologies, but we are unable to accept walk-ins.
10003.title: Help Serve at a Client Accomplishment Dinner

10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Program: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, 1 st -8 th grade students are exposed to intensive academic support in a differentiated classroom setting led by a professional Head Teacher and 2-4 volunteers from 9:30 AM - 12:30 PM. In order to ensure a smooth and effective program, the Community Engagement Administrative Intern will assist the Community Engagement Team during the weekday in critical programmatic and administrative tasks related specifically to volunteer management, such as (but not limited to): posting for volunteers using all social media platforms, participating in volunteer recruitment events, supporting volunteer orientation preparation, submitting background check forms, following up with volunteers for feedback and general communication, and program set-up as needed. Intern will be expected to complete 8-10 hours per week between Tuesdays to Fridays. The exact times during the intern schedule is negotiable. Specific tasks include, but are not limited, to the following: Volunteer Recruitment · Posting volunteer opportunities to all relevant social media platforms on a bi-weekly basis · Responding to volunteer inquiries on the application process · Preparing materials for in-person recruitment events Volunteer Onboarding · Follow up with new volunteer applicants to ensure that they complete the full application process, including: 1) submitting all necessary documents, and 2) scheduling and attending an orientation with a program team member · Welcome volunteers during scheduled orientation time blocks by: 1) checking in new volunteers, 2) supporting them in completing any supplemental documents, 3) answering questions as needed, and 4) assisting the Community Engagement Program Manager with facilitating GO Project orientations only as needed Data Collection and Organization Support with the collection of all volunteer supplemental documents data including online volunteer applications, cover letters & personal statements, resumes & transcripts, letters of recommendation, and background check forms Submit background check forms and update our volunteer database with clearances Electronically file and organize volunteer supplemental documents into our database for new volunteer applicants Volunteer Communication · Contact current new and returning volunteers as needed to: 1) collect necessary paperwork, 2) follow up on program attendance, and/or 3) share communication on special events Volunteer Recognition · Support the Community Engagement Program Manager in creating and updating volunteer recognition materials Administrative Ensure timely response to GO Project emails and phone calls Perform other responsibilities as requested by the GO staff A positive and engaged approach to all designated responsibilities Punctual and consistent attendance Ongoing communication with the Community Engagement Team on tasks and feedback Time Commitment Commitment from September to December (with a possibility of extension to April) 8-10 hours per week from Tuesdays to Fridays (select days and times are negotiable) Location The internship will take place at the main office, located at 50 Cooper Square, 3 rd Floor, New York, NY 10003. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU · Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners · Being part of a vibrant and diverse GO Project community of students, teachers, volunteers, and staff · College credit if applicable Qualifications · Commitment to educational equity a must · Flexibility and adaptability to meet the emerging needs of the program on a day-to-day basis · Ability to manage relationships with a diverse set of community stakeholders · Outgoing and personable demeanor · Professional work habits How to Apply · Cover Letter/Personal Statement · Resume · Personal reference If interested, please e-mail cover letter and resume to Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org. Indicate GO PROJECT INTERN in the subject line. The GO Project is an equal opportunity employer.
10003.title: GO Project Community Engagement Intern

10003.description: Volunteer Certified Long Term Care Ombudsmen are a vital link between residents of long term care facilities and the government resources able to investigate and resolve their problems. Ombudsmen are committed to advocating for these senior citizens and ensuring that residents' rights, unmet needs and complaints are handled and resolved effectively, while maintaining resident and complainant confidentiality. In this way, Ombudsmen protect and help improve the quality of life for the frailest of New York's senior population. Being an Ombudsman is an important responsibility that is taken on with great care and professionalism. In New York State, Ombudsmen are certified only after receiving extensive training. As Ombudsmen take on their duties in assigned facilities, they are supported by a network of fellow Ombudsmen, Coordinators, and the State Office. If you are interested in becoming an ombudsman please contact Mary Jane Wolper mwolper@cidny.org
10003.title: Make a difference become a Long Term Care Ombudsman
10003.org: CIDNY- Long Term Care Ombudsman Program

10003.description: Sirovich Center for Balanced Living is a hub of recreational, social, cultural, educational, and health programming for people aged 60+. We provide breakfast, lunch, and dinner to older adults Monday-Friday as well as leveled exercise classes, health screenings, and a variety of arts and culture classes. In a senior center such as ours, there is always plenty to do, and sharing your time with us is one of the greatest gifts you can give. We are currently looking for volunteer to help out our dinner program with meal prep and/or dinner service. You will be: Working with a multi-generational team of teens, college students, young adults, and senior adults who will grow and develop the dinner program Meet new friends and make a lasting impact on the people you meet Gain leadership and relationship-building skills Have to be comfortable on your feet Duties can include: Prepare meals, meal service, helping with clean up, delivering smiles to our participants. Time Commitment: Volunteers serve flexible hours from Monday-Friday, 3:30-7pm On average, volunteers serve a minimum 2-7 of hours per week Minimum 1 day a week commitment required for least 3 months. Requirements: must be steady on your feet, stay focused on delivering meals without getting caught up in conversations, and willing to wear plastic gloves, apron, and a glamorous hairnet. We also welcome those who are interested in signing up for just one night of dinner service or would like to sign up to volunteer sporadically. Please register for dinner services using this link http://www.edalliance.org/volunteer. It will prompt you to create a volunteer profile, please fill it out to best of your knowledge and afterwards you will be able to search for \"Serving Dinner to Older Adults at Sirovich\" and sign up for the dates you prefer. If you run into any problems please email Trevor Martindale at tmartindale@edalliance.org
10003.title: Have Fun Prepping and Serving Dinner At Sirovich Senior Center

10003.description: Read about KittyKind at www.kittykind.org KittyKind is all-volunteer cat rescue and cat adoption group located in the Petco store on 17th Street and Broadway, in space that the Petco Corporation donates. KittyKind relies upon donations for all other expenses. It relies upon volunteers to care for the rescued cats. A Health-Maintenance volunteer helps to give nutritional supplements, eye cream, and veterinarian-prescribed medication to cats awaiting adoption at the KittyKind adoption center. Training and training materials will be given. The volunteer shift would be for a couple of hours, one day a week, throughout the year. After training, the day and the time are up to you. Preference is for a volunteer who has experience working with animals or who is a pre-vet, or a vet-tech student. However, all help is welcome. For Saturday or Sunday help, please be an \"early bird,\" able to start about 8 or 9, before the adoption center gets crowded. Must be over age 18. Active seniors very welcome! References preferred. To begin the application process, please do the following: Connect to kittykind.org Click on Volunteer Fill out an application, specifying Health Maintenance as your preference Then, someone will email you shortly after. Thanks.
10003.title: Health Care: Cats/Kittens

10003.description: We need a person(s) with a car to spend 1 hour (between 9:30 and 10:30am) on Saturdays to pick up donated food in the neighborhood from in-kind donors. We pick up from Au Bon Pain, Blimpies, Jon Vie Pasteries, Balducci's, D'Agostino's, etc. all in Soho and the Village.
10003.title: To pick up food with a car on Sat. mornings

10003.description: We feed 150 homeless and needy people every Saturday. Volunteers are invited to arrive about 9:00am until about 12:00pm to help in the preparation of food and soup by chopping vegatables, slicing bread, making sandwiches, arranging desserts, etc. No need to make a reservation - just show up and we'll put you to work although groups must be limited to 5 people please. A different group organized by NYCares serves the meals in the later afternoon. We are also in need of a person(s), with a car, to pick up food from in-kind donors in the neighborhood on Sat. mornings (ie. Sullivan Steet Bread, Knickeboker Restaurant, Chipolte, etc.) and bring the donated food to our Soup Kitchen so it can be prepared for serving. E-mail Dean directly if you can help in this endeavor.
10003.title: To help feed the needy

10167.description: Cents Ability, Inc. teaches underserved teens the basics of financial literacy. Any educated and motivated adult may apply, however, preference is given to financial professionals.
10167.title: Volunteer Teacher of Financial Literacy

10008.description: The Youth Voices Network is a group of volunteers who have had personal experience with dating abuse and/or intimate partner violence before the age of 24*. Meetings are held on the final Thursday of every month at 6:30pm in downtown Manhattan. Exact location will be disclosed upon acceptance. Ability to attend meetings is strongly preferred, but not required, for participation. Please get in touch to discuss your individual schedule! (*Age limit only pertains to the experience itself; applicants of any age are considered for membership.) The primary aims of the group are to: Let young people know that they are not alone Prevent dating abuse by increasing community awareness Promote discussion about the factors of healthy and unhealthy relationships Direct survivors to helpful resources In the 2016-2017 year we were proud to meet these aims through a variety of different opportunities. Members have shared stories with one another, youth/peers, government officials, and the media. The Youth Voices Network has also hosted several events in an effort to highlight individual talents/showcase methods of healing. Examples include: How the Media Can End Rape Culture discussion panel New Voices open mic for Sexual Assault Awareness Month Ongoing speaking engagements at Day One trainings And many more. We are always tailoring what we provide to member interest. Bring your ideas, we are happy to have them! The Youth Voices Network is a safe space to foster healthy relationships. Humans of all races, religions, genders, and sexualities are welcome. To complete an application, please visit http://www.dayoneny.org/join-the-youth-voices-network/ To submit the application, or for more information, please email us at youthvoicesnetwork@dayoneny.org.
10008.title: Prevent Dating Abuse - Join the Youth Voices Network!

10009.description: Our Manhattan based organization is seeking a cohort of approximately 5 tech savvy volunteers who would work in our computer center with our team leader to assist the homeless population we serve by providing the Homeless guests computer access. The tech volunteer will also be needed to support computer access for the social services team. Our hours of operation are every Saturday from 8 AM to 3:00PM and we are located at 137 East Second Street, (at Avenue A in Manhattan) at the Cardinal Spellman Center (lower level). 2nd Avenue stop on the F train. Our space is equipped with wireless Internet, computers and printers and a full supply of stationary for volunteers to assist our guests. All volunteers would have a tremendous amount of staff support. Please have the interested parties contact Joe Montano, Director at 347-534-7792 or through email at emailucss-ny@yahoo.com
10009.title: Techies needed to support Computer Center at The Meatloaf Kitchen

10009.description: Hundreds of families seek mentoring services through CBSBB each year - we can’t serve them without volunteers like you! While we are need of all types of volunteers across New York City, we have a pressing need for Spanish volunteer mentors starting late fall / early winter 2017. A Match is... The relationship between a Big (volunteer mentor) and a Little (mentee) Bigs serve as positive role models and friends who help Littles set and accomplish goals Bigs and Littles plan and participate in fun activities together which form a lasting impact for both individuals Supported by a Match Coordinator (Masters level social worker or equivalent) at the agency Bigs are ... 21 years old or older Interested in mentoring a Little of the same gender, age 7-17, who lives in the five boroughs Willing and able to finance match outings (low or no-cost outings are highly encouraged) Willing to pick up / drop off Little for outings if the Little doesn’t travel independently From all walks of life! Men, people of color, volunteers ages 50+, individuals of all faith backgrounds, and Spanish speakers highly encouraged to apply Big and Little matches connect... Over time: Bigs and Littles each commit to the match relationship for at least one year Face-to-face: twice per month for about eight total hours (usually on the weekends) Over the phone: once weekly to catch up To learn skills: workshops are offered throughout the year at the CBSBB office for hands-on match support and skill-building CBSBB is... Founded in 1902, the mission of Catholic Big Sisters Big Brothers is to address the social, emotional and academic challenges facing youth living in New York City’s low-income neighborhoods by providing one-to-one community based mentoring services supported by life skills programming, crisis intervention, family support and referral assistance. We seek to improve the lives of children of all faiths, empowering them to recognize, reach for and achieve their full potential as self-sufficient adults. Many of CBSBB’s Littles are youth from first-generation and/or low-income families. Our mentees face poverty, a shortage of practical skills, and a lack of exposure to opportunities in NYC. Bigs who serve with CBSBB make a difference in the lives of their Littles! 92% of CBSBB 12th grade students graduate high school and 83% of CBSBB high school graduates enter college or a job training program, compared to 50% of their peers. Interested? Contact us... On the internet: cbsbb.org/volunteers On the phone: 212-475-3291 x502 On social media: Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram Mentoring not a good fit right now? Get in touch to learn how you can support us with volunteer recruitment, donor cultivation, and other engagement opportunities at CBSBB.
10009.title: Change a Life.  Change Your Life.  Spanish Speaking Mentors Needed!

10009.description: Our Manhattan based organization is seeking a cohort of approximately 12 volunteers who would work with our homeless population on a scheduled rotating basis in teams of two or three workers weekly to assist us with intakes, assessments and referrals. Our hours of operation are every Saturday from 8 AM to 3:00PM and we are located at 137 East Second Street, (at Avenue A in Manhattan) at the Cardinal Spellman Center (lower level). 2nd Avenue stop on the F train. Our space is equipped with wireless Internet, computers and printers and a full supply of stationary for volunteers to assist our guests. All volunteers would have a tremendous amount of staff support. Please have the interested parties contact Joe Montano, Director at 347-534-7792 or through email at emailucss-ny@yahoo.com
10009.title: Volunteers needed to provide homeless with social services.

11510.description: The Clerical Assistant will assist with clerical duties such as filing, faxing, copying, telephone coverage and data entry.
11510.title: Clerical Assistant- CWI

11510.description: South Nassau Communities Hospital-Home Care Department Volunteer needed 2-3 times per week-Monday-Friday-anytime between 9am-5pm. (4hr shifts) Responsibilities may include: filing,collating, data entry, phone coverage and general clerical duties.
11510.title: Clerical Assistant- Home Care

08852.description: Contact us for more information on working with hospice patients close to where you live. We provide FREE volunteer training for you along with free TB and Rubella/Rubeola testing. Your pet will need to be a certified pet therapy animal. You and your pet will bring joy and love to the lives of our patients and will receive so much love and joy in return!
08852.title: Share your pet's unconditional love with hospice patients!

08852.description: Pack meals for the Meals On Wheels Program and serve lunch to the seniors in the building. No cooking just dishing food from steam table. Hours one day week 8:30-12:30. Weekdays only.
08852.title: Kitchen Assistant

08852.description: Greet older adults coming to use gym in the senior center. Verify they are on approved list and have medical clearance to enter. Monitor seniors in gym. Shifts 8:30-12:30 and 12:30-3:00 at least one day per week. Weekdays only. High school students in July and August. Adults Sept-June.
08852.title: Gym Greeter

08852.description: Be the first point of contact for seniors entering the senior center. Check for membership. Help them scan in to our attendance computerized program. Answer simple questions. Direct members of the public to the offices. Shifts 8:30-12:00 and 12:00-3:00 weekdays only. No weekends Adults used Sept-June and High Shchool students in the summer
08852.title: Greeter

08857.description: If you have an hour or more per week to give, Ascend Hospice welcomes your gifts of time and compassion. Whether you choose to work directly with patients and families or to volunteer in one of many other ways, you can make a profound difference in someone's life, including your own. Volunteers are an integral part of the hospice team. Ascend Hospice serves counties throughout New Jersey. Areas where you are needed include: Atlantic County, Bergen County, Cape May County, Essex County, Hudson County, Mercer County, Middlesex County, Monmouth County, Morris County, North Passaic County, Ocean County, Somerset County, South Passaic County, Burlington County, Camden County and Union County. Sometimes all it takes is a smile or sharing a story to make somone feel important. All Modalities are welcome. Volunteer Opportunities: Companionship Volunteers work directly with patients providing companionship, offering friendly visits, reading to patients, writing letters, offering a gentle touch or sharing a quiet moment. Complementary Volunteers are certified/trained professionals who can provide complementary modalities of reflexologly, music, Reiki, & massage. Ascend Hospice is seeking certified Reiki practioners to serve our end of life population in finding comfort, relaxation and peace during their final time with us. Your assistance is needed with reducing anxiety, relieving pain and providing a safe , comfortable environment. Training provided for volunteers. Reiki Certification is required. Pet Therapy Volunteers provide companionship from our certified therapy dogs. Pet therapy provides numerous benefits like encouraging movement and physical stimulation and it provides mental benefits like socialization, mental stimulation, companionship, and unconditional love. Please consider sharing your loving pet with us and bring some much needed smiles. Pets must be certified as therapy animals by an organization like TDI Therapy Dogs International- see website here http://www.tdi-dog.org/ Music Volunteers are volunteers who specialize in sharing songs or instrumental music with patients and their loved ones. Whether the Music Volunteer is sharing an existing musical skill or playing music via the radio or digital device, the goal is to enhance the quality of life of our patients. Often, regularly scheduled visits are requested, however Music Volunteers may also be asked to provide musical visits on an occasional basis for one patient/family or for a group of patients at a facility as outreach for the local hospice agency. Hospice is built on the philosophy that we care for our patients in mind, body and soul. Craft Volunteers consist of individuals or groups who touch patients in a special way by making lap blankets, shawls, memory bears and other articles for patients to enjoy. Bereavement Volunteers offer support to the families of patients who have passed. During the grieving process the bereavement volunteer can be a valuable resource, especially for those who lack a solid support network. They often make phone calls to check up on family members and also send cards of comfort and care. For more information about our free volunteer training and available opportunities, call our Volunteer Department or visit our website at Ascendhospice.com! We look forward to hearing from you! Please do not contact me with unsolicited services or offers.
08857.title: Hospice Volunteers - Companion, Music, Pet Therapy, Reiki - Old Bridge

08857.description: General assistance to Envionmental Services department. Volunteer should like working with their hands. General cleaning, windows, sweeping, walking the grounds for trash pickup, helping maintenance staff with preventative maintenance issues.
08857.title: Maintenance Support Volunteer

08857.description: To provide patients the opportunity to interact with trained and certified dogs during their hospitalization to improve thieir emotional and social status.
08857.title: Pet Therapy (Old Bridge)

08857.description: Catholic Charities Connections Program is actively recruiting volunteers to work as mentors with children ages 5-17. Mentors offer support, guidance, and education as a youth goes through a difficult time, faces new challenges or opportunities, or takes on an important task. A mentor is a person who is willing to share their life-long expertise to provide support to the youth. Mentors can play an important role as the youth develops mentally and emotionally to help a youth understand their goals and personal needs. Mentors must be a minimum of 18 years of age. Prospective mentors will undergo an intensive screening process consisting of: application and informal autobiography, personal interview, reference checks, criminal background check, driving record check and program orientation. The program serves youth in Middlesex County. Mentoring is the process of sharing personal knowledge and skills with a young person.
08857.title: Mentoring Youth

06906.description: Caring Hospice Services of Connecticut is a unique, holistic and cost effective service designed to meet the social, emotional, spiritual and physical needs of their patients and families as they face terminal illness. The mission of Caring Hospice is to coordinate patient and family services while respecting their choices, values and beliefs. Caring Hospice Services has patients in communities throughout Fairfield County and New Haven County residing in private homes, nursing homes and assisted living. We are looking for individuals who are willing to commit to a consistent schedule a few hours per week or every other week. Currently, we have variety of Volunteer Opportunities such as Office Support, Patient Visits, Arts & Crafts support, Music Volunteer and Bereavement Support. Individualized training is provided free of charge. In keeping with Medicare requirements, background and medical checks are part of the training process.
06906.title: Variety of volunteer support

06906.description: You can make a difference in the life of a child, right here in our community. Done-in-a-Day Opportunities Books Across Stamford: Motivating children to read through the distribution of free books & resources! This event occurs in November & April at the Ferguson Library. Family Literacy Night: While parents of Springdale Elementary School's English Language Learner students are participating in workshops, join us in reading to children, distributing books, doing craft projects, and serving food! Ongoing Opportunities Traditional Mentoring Program: Provides middle and high school students who need additional academic and/or social support with the resources and guidance required to be successful. This program pairs mentors with the same student for weekly one-on-one sessions to foster the development of a meaningful relationship. Success Plan Workshop: Targeted at high school students, this program prepares each student for post-high school success by pairing with mentors to work on completing the Naviance-based college and career readiness activities, mandated by the CT Student Success Plan.
06906.title: Become a Volunteer. Change a Life.

06906.description: Office support volunteers help our staff with basic tasks such as answering the phone, copying and assembling packets, helping with web research, and more. If you are a person who demonstrates the ability to communicate with people effectively, has absolute integrity and the use of good judgment to handle the professional and confidential nature of assignments, then Caring Hospice of Connecticut located in Stamford, Connecticut is the right fit for you. We are looking for individuals who are willing to commit to a consistent schedule a few hours per week or every other week. Individualized training is provided free of charge. In keeping with Medicare requirements, background and medical checks are part of the training process.
06906.title: Become an office support volunteer!

06906.description: Office volunteers are needed to help support the wonderful Caring Hospice team in preparing for their daily tasks in the field of caring for our patients. These skill sets in organized prep work will assist greatly for our team. By providing an ease when our staff goes to visit patients and their families. Individualized training is provided in the Stamford office. In keeping with Medicare requirements, background and medical checks are part of the training process. Thank youi
06906.title: Office Volunteers

06907.description: This lady who is blind and uses a guide dog is looking for a shopping buddy for occasional trips to the mall and for groceries. She is a an adult college student pursuing her Masters Degree in Special Education. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06907.title: Lady and Guide Dog Looking for a Shopping Buddy
06907.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06905.description: Have you seen What About Bob? Do you understand what it is like to live and work with Bob or even to be Bob? Can you be kind and compassionate to Bob. Can you listen with patience to the same story week after week because you are there for them and not for yourself? Two special volunteers are needed to provide friendly visiting, light reading (this individual is blind), and calm, soothing affirmation to someone who feels anxious about their world. You are not asked to provide treatment of any sort - JUST LISTEN AND CHAT - and no real experience is needed however you should be prepared to experience repetition and perseverant thinking - similar to someone with an aging or memory deficit. This individual likes to hear math and science, appreciates punctuality, responds well to authority figures, or those who are meticulous with self-assured bumptious personalities! Is this you? Requirements to be a great volunteer include: PATIENCE a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references your own transportation or access to bus route;
06905.title: What About Bob? Do You Know The Movie?
06905.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06905.description: Stamford Dollars for Scholars is an all-volunteer nonprofit community organization whose mission is to provide scholarships to support local students in their pursuit of higher education. The Student Outreach Volunteer is an advocate for Stamford Dollars for Scholars, working as a team with the Student Outreach Coordinators to communicate with high school guidance counselors, provide scholarship application workshops to high school seniors, and to represent Stamford Dollars for Scholars at local events and college fairs. This position is a non-paid volunteer. We do not have an office so as-needed coordination by phone or in-person meetings will be necessary. The Student Outreach Volunteer is expected to work independently and schedule time to meet the objectives provided by the Coordinator. A minimum commitment of 4 hours per week between September and April is required. You may be requested to meet with students during a typical workday. Qualifications Exceptional communication skills. Experience working with high school students or familiarity with scholarship or college application process. Demonstrated ability to work with computers. Self-directed, able to work autonomously, while understanding that collaboration will be essential. Must be able to schedule workshops during school hours. Must be available one to two evenings total to attend local college fairs. College or graduate students, entrepreneurs, retirees welcome.
06905.title: Student Outreach Volunteer

06902.description: Our amazing volunteer Book Lady has given away over 40,000 books since she started filling our 2 community carts three years ago. Are you free Monday mornings between 10 and 11:30 to help haul boxes a few feet, place books on the shelves, and have fun with a a couple dozen three year olds who visit the carts. Not only is it a dream volunteer job, but Book Lady Lorrie is as wonderful as they come.
06902.title: Help our Book Lady on Monday Mornings

06902.description: We have a few retired veterans here at Brighton Gardens of Stamford who would like to share their stories with people. Not much is required other than interest and spending 45 minutes per week with them and even that is flexible. Call or email if you are interested. Thank you!
06902.title: Any local Veterans out there willing to come in and spend time with retirees?

06902.description: Administrative Help needed to support the mission of our free clinics. Americares Free Clinics provides primary health care services to residents Connecticut residents who are low income and have no health insurance. We have an immediate need for someone to help with data entry in our medical billing system. Candidate must be conscientious and detail oriented. Familiarity with medical billing systems (especially Medisoft) is a big plus, but not required. Work will be done at our HQ at 88 Hamilton Avenue. Ideal candidate will be able to volunteer two times per week for 2 hours.
06902.title: Administrative help needed with medical data entry

06902.description: We need volunteers to help out during the Christmas season ! For more information cal our office at: 203-359-2320
06902.title: We need volunteers

06902.description: Our delightful director of human resources and director of training have finally maxed out their bandwidth! They could use help with a variety of administrative tasks including: file/photo copy data entry: knowledge of Excel required create new hire packets and training certificates create electronic files and update contact information help with holiday decorations
06902.title: Administrative Help during the Week

06902.description: Clothes To Kids of Fairfield County is looking for 1-2 volunteers to undertake the day to day tasks of initiating, pursuing and cultivating relationships with local organizations and companies for possible future partnerships in clothing drives & event sponsorship. Volunteer work can be done remotely and on the volunteer's schedule and work will be overseen by a current Clothes To Kids of Fairfield County volunteer and Board member.
06902.title: Corporate Relations Volunteer
06902.org: CLOTHES TO KIDS OF FAIRFIELD COUNTY INC

06902.description: Clothes To Kids of Fairfield County is ready to grow and needs your help! We are currently looking for volunteers to help with school outreach. This would include reaching out to private schools to create partnerships for clothing drives and reaching out to public schools to make sure they are aware of CTKF and the service that we are providing to the Fairfield County, CT Community. Volunteers in this role would have a flexible schedule and outreach could be done based on the volunteer's schedule with regular communication and regular update meetings with the executive director of CTKF.
06902.title: Help Clothes To Kids of Fairfield County provide clothing to kids in need!
06902.org: CLOTHES TO KIDS OF FAIRFIELD COUNTY INC

06902.description: Clothes To Kids of Fairfield County is looking for volunteers to help fill a variety of positions, some examples of which are detailed below. Since we are a new non-profit in the Fairfield County area this is an opportunity to get involved early and help us grow! 1. Outreach - Volunteer to help coordinate outreach to social services, public school administrators, private school administrators and Fairfield County clothing stores to help spread the word about Clothes To Kids of Fairfield County. 2. Inventory - volunteer to participate in an inventory day when we organize and take inventory of recent clothing donations. This is a volunteer opportunity in which highschool kids may participate. 3. Marketing - Spent some time working from home and help spread the word about Clothes To Kids of Fairfield County. Although our store is located in Stamford, CT many of our volunteer opportunities can be done remotely, such as our outreach volunteer positions, and there are additional volunteer opportunities other than those listed above. **Note - although some of our volunteer opportunities may be done remotely one requirement is that you live in or near Fairfield County, CT.
06902.title: Help Clothes To Kids of FC provide clothing to low-income children in Fairfield County CT!
06902.org: CLOTHES TO KIDS OF FAIRFIELD COUNTY INC

06902.description: The Child Guidance Center of Southern Connecticut (CGC) is currently seeking volunteers for its Youth, Empowerment, & Support (YES) Mentoring Program. The YES Mentoring Program will provide children, ages 6-18, with an opportunity to enjoy recreational activities and engage in positive relationships with members of our community. As a YES mentor, you will be serving as a positive role model for an at-risk youth and participate in fun, age-appropriate activities with a child, establishing a positive social relationship. While you are spending quality time with the child/teen, you're also providing their parent(s) with some much needed self-care time. Each YES session lasts 12 weeks, and you will be required to meet with the child/teen for three hours a week. Every mentor will complete a thorough interview, orientation, and background check. The mentor and family will work together to develop a convenient schedule of enjoyable activities for the child. To volunteer, please contact Sheila Figueroa at (203) 517-3346 or sheila.figueroa@childguidancect.org.
06902.title: Seeking Mentors for At-Risk Youth
06902.org: CHILD GUIDANCE CENTER OF SOUTHERN CT INC

06902.description: A local young adult needs a mentor for community inclusion activities. He loves music and adapted computers, but due to blindness he cannot drive so he has a difficult time accessing social activities and work opportunities. If you are interested, you will attend community events, concerts, attend movies, go on a short walk, or explore work opportunities by helping him obtain applications and returning them for consideration. This is a great opportunity to spend some time in your community while helping another person. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06902.title: Mentor and Community Inclusion Buddy Needed for Local Fellow with Blindness
06902.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06902.description: BILINGUAL (SPANISH-ENGLISH) ADMINISTRATIVE VOLUNTEER needed for Stamford Americares Free Clinic. Need conversational Spanish. We need volunteers to help with registering patients, returning patient calls and making appointments. Come join our team of caring professionals.
06902.title: BILINGUAL ADMINISTRATIVE HELP  needed for Stamford AmeriCares Free Clinic

06902.description: Stigma leaves me stuck and I need to make a new good friend who will read to me and visit with me at my group home. If you like discussing current events, reading and visiting this is a perfect match for you. I like to learn grammar and vocabulary or read about minerals, food and nutrition or related topics. I might repeat myself so I just need you to be patient with me while we get to know each other. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06902.title: Stigma Leaves Me Stuck - Will You Read to Me?
06902.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06902.description: VOLUNTEER Medical Assistants or EMTs are needed for our very busy AmeriCares mobile clinic located in Stamford CT. If you are an experienced medical assistant or EMT, we can use your help. Our free clinic treats low income, uninsured residents of Stamford. The clinic sessions are: Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday afternoons from noon to 5:00. Volunteers can work a 4 hour shift that works with their schedule. Come join our team of committed and compassionate professionals! You can volunteer once a week or once a month. We are flexible and will work with your schedule. Please see our website for more information about our program, AmericaresFreeClinics.org or email Lorraine Larkin at llarkin@americares.org
06902.title: EMT or Medical Assistants needed at Stamford AmeriCares Free Clinic

06902.description: VOLUNTEER NURSES are needed for our busy AmeriCares free clinic located in Stamford CT. Our clinic has recently been relocated to a beautiful and spacious location at 401 Shippan Avenue. Our free clinic treats low income, uninsured residents of Stamford. Volunteers’ shifts are 12:30 to 4:30 pm on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursdays. We are flexible and will work with your schedule. Come join our team of committed and compassionate professionals! You can volunteer once a week or once a month. It is up to you. Please see our website for more information about our program, AmericaresFreeClinics.org or email Lorraine Larkin at llarkin@americares.org
06902.title: Volunteer Nurses needed at Stamford americares free clinic

06902.description: Love to cook? Purchase and prepare a healthy, homecooked, delicious, and complete meal in your kitchen or the commercial kitchen in our school, and deliver it to 10 hungry teenage boys - once, once-a-month, or when it's convenient. Your help is budget relieving, and lets staff spend more one-on-one time with our group home boys who would be homeless except for Domus. To know more, write me and I'll provide additional details.
06902.title: Meal Preparation for our Group Home Boys

06902.description: Do you have a curiosity about global affairs? Lead a U.S. foreign policy discussion group today! For over 55 years, the Foreign Policy Association's Great Decisions program has brought together people and communities to encourage individuals to engage in the world around them and to think critically about the global issues facing policymakers. Each year, FPA produces the Great Decisions briefing book, examining eight U.S. foreign policy and global affairs topics. All across the U.S., discussion groups meet to consider and discuss these topics, constituting the largest civil-education network in the country. Discussion group leaders organize and lead these meetings in their communities. Become a group leader now!
06902.title: Lead a global affairs discussion in the Stamford area today!!

06903.description: Historic Home Docent & Museum Greeter We are looking for volunteers who would like to introduce visitors to our 1699 historic house museum, The Hoyt-Barnum House. You would be involved with greeting visitors with a smile and giving a brief explanation of the Center's offerings: a research library, photo archive, our current exhibit, and our historic house museum. People who wish to tour Hoyt-Barnum House first view an introductory film before starting the audio tour. You would be responsible for selling tickets and recording transactions, giving guests their audio pods and collecting them after the tours, opening and closing up the house museum, and monitoring visitors while they are in the house. Training is provided. Museum Docents should be friendly and personable. They should be physically able to manage stairs and brief walks on a regular basis. Docents should be at least 20 years old and able to work at least one four-hour day, 2 x /month. Docents are needed for Thursdays and Fridays. Shifts are from noon to 3:15 pm on Thursdays and Fridays. Two docents are needed on Saturday: one from 10:30 - 1:00 and one from1:00 to 3:30 pm. You are welcome to stay longer to meet our other volunteers and make use of our facility. Check out our Website for loads of fun information: http://stamfordhistory.org/ Skills Customer Service Public Speaking General Education Problem Solving Communication Basic math/money skills Hope to hear from you soon! Tom Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator & Board Member Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org volunteer@stamfordhistory.org (O) 203-329-1183 (C) 917-701-3572
06903.title: Tour Guide & Greeter: Historic Home

06903.description: Assistant Treasurer with the following duties: Reviews weekly cash deposits Receive, organize and pay bills Input accounting activity into Quickbooks Closing accounting books on monthly, quarterly and annual basis Organizing and archiving financial records Hours are flexible: Thursday, Fridays & Saturdays between 10:00 and 12:00 If you fit the bill and would like to help us, please get in touch with me. Thanks for your interest! Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator - Board Member Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org volunteer@stamfordhistory.org (O) 203-329-1183 (C) 917-701-3572
06903.title: Assistant Treasurer / Bookeeper

06903.description: Media/News Writer Volunteer, If you enjoy writing, this is the volunteer job for you. We are looking for someone to create press releases about the Stamford History Center for distribution to various media outlets (onlinenews sites, radio, tv, magazines, etc.). You will interview people in the organization to gather information. Once your article is reviewed by our volunteer editors, it will be sent out. It is essential that our media volunteer stays up-to- date with our activities, so press releases go out in a timely fashion. The position can be expanded to include the creation of newsletters and flyers (working with our graphic designer). This is a job that can be done largely from your own laptop/desktop, and at your own convenience. REQUIREMENT: Please write a two or three paragraph \"Press Release\" on one of the following topics: 1] About our Tag Sale 2] The opening of the Hoyt-Barnum House or 3] A past Historical Center event You can get ideas by going to our web site: www.stamfordhistory.org Forward it to me and we will review and get back to you. Thanks again for your interest in joining the volunteer team! Tom Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org 203-329-1183 Skills needed: organized, experienced writer; a self-starter who can use Word and navigate the internet.
06903.title: Media/News Writer Volunteer

06903.description: Conservative - Erudite - Patient - Reader / Visitor Needed A local fellow needs a reader and visitor to chat and read and pass the time. This gent is very socially isolated but loves to chat is very socially conscious, well mannered and has goals and dreams for himself. Do you have 2 hours per week to spend reading and chatting with him? He lives in a group setting that offers both common rooms as well as non-public spaces for meeting and reading. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06903.title: Conservative - Erudite - Patient - Bookish Reader Needed
06903.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

11203.description: Kingsbrook is seeking volunteers with excellent communication skills to help enroll our patients in the Patient Portal, Kingsbrook's Electronic Health Record. You will interact with patients and families, educating on the benefits and importance of access to the electronic health record. You will work side by side and be supported by the Patient Portal Analyst. Late afternoon/early evening availability is required.
11203.title: Patient Support Volunteer

11203.description: Do you live or work in Flatbush/EastFlatbush? We are looking for kind, patient, firendly volunteers who are interested in getting to know their frail and/or hombound older neighbors. Become a Friendly Visitor and spend a few hours a week walking and/or visiting with an isolated older neighbor who will benefit from your company!
11203.title: Flatbush and East Flatbush needs Friendly Visiting volunteers!

11203.description: Share healthy living information with children through storytelling, games, puppets, hrough mixed media. Engage children in learning about healthy eating and lifestyle. Encourage patient attendance with nutritional conversation and activities.
11203.title: Super Sprowtz Children'sVolunteer

11203.description: Welcome patients, family and other visitors to the Clinic; answer questions, assist patients in navigating the clinic. Perform ther duties as assigned such as clerical, running errands,etc.
11203.title: Family Health Center Greeter

11203.description: Volunteers are needed to provide companionship and socialization with patients and long term care residents during mealtimes. In as little as one hour per day, you can make a difference in the lives of Kingsbrook's patients and residents!
11203.title: Meal Companions/Feeders

11203.description: Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center's Volunteer Greeters offer a warm greeting to patients and visitors! Greeters provide directions, escort patients and visitors and answer basic questions (visiting hours, cafeteria location, etc.). Volunteers are assigned to one or more 2 hour shifts between 8 am and 7 pm weekdays or weekends. Fluency in Haitian Creole, Spanish or Russian is helpful but not required. Volunteers must be able to present themselves professionally and project an enthusiasm for helping others.
11203.title: Kingsbrook Greeters

11203.description: The role of a Patient Support volunteer is to work as part of the patient care team as directed by Nursing. The Patient Support volunteer provides a warm and welcoming atmosphere for patients, families and visitors. The Department of Volunteer Services gives general orientation including Safety, Infection Control, Patients' Rights, HIPAA and other important information. Nursing staff provides orientation to patient care and on-the-job instruction. While on duty, the Patient Support volunteer is required to wear a volunteer vest provided by the Department of Volunteer Services. Duties: Makes continuous patient rounds on assigned units. Welcomes patients following their admission and assists in obtaining supplies (i.e. blankets, pillows, phone and TV hook up). Visit with patients and their families, offering conversation and emotional support. Dispenses water to patients and assist with meals, with supervising nurse's guidance and approval. Provides information regarding visiting hours, food service and Chaplaincy services. Distributes amenities, as requested and appropriate, including daily newspapers, magazines, books, games, etc. Reads with patients upon request. Walks with patients, with supervising nurse's guidance and approval. Assists patient to make phone calls. Communicates concerns to Patient Representative, Nurse Manager and other staff, as appropriate. Works cooperatively with all employees on unit to ensure patients are cared for courteously and promptly. Such responsibilities may include assisting staff from time to time with non-medical tasks. Maintains established departmental policies and procedures, objectives, quality improvement program, safety, and infection control standards. Promotes adherence to Patients' Bill of Rights. Assimilates core values - compassion, respect, ethics, excellence and dedication - throughout all processes. Communicates effectively and efficiently with patient, family, staff and other members of the health care team. Maintains confidentiality. Reports to duty as scheduled and on time. Adheres to Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center dress code for volunteers.
11203.title: Patient Support Volunteer

11203.description: Volunteers provide general office assistance at the direction of departmental staff. Duties may include answering phones, light typing, labeling, filing and running errands.
11203.title: Clerical Support Volunteer

06901.description: Stamford Academy serves about 135 high school students who have been unsuccessful within the traditional school model. The ratio of students with Individual Education Plans (IEP) is about twice the rate of Stamford Public Schools, yet Stamford is able to provide only one SPED teacher. You know how important one-on-one instruction is. Do you have a couple of hours to spare once a week during the school year to help tutor a student? Training provided. To meet our kids is to love them. They are wary and giving; have big dreams and struggle to stay on task; are talented and funny; and may have not had dinner the night before. If you'd like to know more, please contact me.
06901.title: Do you know what an IEP is? If so, read on...

06901.description: Stamford Academy serves about 135 high school students who have been unsuccessful within the traditional school model. The ratio of students with IEPs is about twice the rate of Stamford Public Schools, yet Stamford is able to provide only one SPED teacher. Do you have a couple of hours to spare once a week during the school year to help with one-on-one tutoring? To meet our kids is to love them. They are wary and giving; have big dreams and struggle to stay on task; are talented and funny; and may have not had dinner the night before. If you'd like to know more, please contact me.
06901.title: Retired SPED Teachers & Para Educators Wanted

06901.description: Our kids are generally behind their peers in math and need extra help to close the gap. They are also, loving, funny, and want to improve their skills. You can help by working one-on-one with a high school student from Stamford Academy or Stamford High School. To know more, contact me and I'll put you in touch with their advocate.
06901.title: Math Tutors

06901.description: We are seeking volunteers for the 2017 LIGHT THE NIGHT events coming up on the following dates: We need help the week of October 23 and October 30 (at our Stamford location) preparing the lanterns for our participants to light up. So anyone who can help out for even a few hours, please call! Hope you will encourage anyone interested to contact me and come help us LIGHT UP THE NIGHT! Sincerely, Megan Johnson Leukemia & Lymphoma Society 203-388-9175 Megan.Johnson@lls.org
06901.title: Help needed to assemble lanterns for our walk.
06901.org: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society Connecticut Westchester Hudson Valley Chapter - Stamford Office

06901.description: Declare Your Dedication to a Better Stamford! Be a Reader to the Blind and help make Connecticut a better place to live. If you like to chat, read current news affairs, shop a little, walk a little and love life a lot, this is the chance you have been waiting for. Four new volunteer positions in Stamford and one in Norwalk will become open within the next few weeks. Here is a little overview of what's available: 1.. gent needs a well read, inquiring and patient mind to discuss science, space and all manner of interesting topics. There will be a bit of reading science magazines or other news of mutual agreement, even a few library materials would be welcome; 2...lady and her guide dog need a sighted guide buddy to walk the local area incuding paths to the beach, conference center and other areas. She would also like to go to the library, shopping or out for coffee and a little shopping; 3... two ladies who are both socially isolated and who want to get out to shop, attend local performances, speeches, conferences, presentations and outdoor concerts. Both would enjoy shopping for clothes, curios, and groceries. 4...gent in Norwalk and his service dog needs a socialization buddy, he has a very high intelligence level and no peers locally to share his knowledge, expertise or interests. Visits will largely be on site in a common area and then if mutually agreed, outings will be of interest. Get in on the Ground Floor of this great volunteer opportunity and do your part to make Connecticut a great place to live, work and socialize. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06901.title: Declare Your Dedication to a Better Stamford! Be a Reader and Buddy to the Blind
06901.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06901.description: The SustainAbilityCT (iACT) project focuses on economic solutions that drive employment, education and housing. Recognizing that economic stability is the most important predictor of an individual’s ability to permanently exit an abusive relationship, DVCC created iACT to help victims achieve financial security through numerous resources, including financial education workshops, resume preparation, job search strategies, and connection to job training programs and affordable housing resources. The goal is that clients become financially savvy, self-confident and in control of every aspect of their lives. The SustainAbilityCT program of DVCC is looking for professionals who can assist our clients and staff in areas of: Debt planning; Mortgages; Automotive financing; Family Law;Consumer law; CPA; Financial Literacy; Tax laws and more. If you think you have a skill or competency that will help our clients we would love to talk to you.
06901.title: Skilled Professionals

06901.description: Domestic Violence Crisis Center (DVCC) is committed to promoting the fundamental right of all individuals to be safe in their personal relationships. The EparanzaCT program is an arm of the DVCC that serves the Latino population in the Fairfield County area. We serve six towns in CT: Stamford, Norwalk, Darien, New Canaan, Westport & Wilton. There is an immediate need for volunteers who speak Spanish. We have opportunities in In-take (Health centers & ER), Hotline, Medical Advocacy Program, Sustainability program (ESL classes, computer instruction, financial planning, Tax help etc.) Please note training is required and DVCC will provide the training at no cost to you but we need a 3-6 month commitment towards the opportunity.
06901.title: Spanish speaking volunteers

06901.description: Similar to the book cart program in front of our Lockwood Avenue campus, we'd like to start a neighborhood give-away book cart in front of Stamford Academy, our high school on North Street. The books come from the community, your friends shelves, and local libraries. If you have 2 hours a week, a flexible schedule, your own transportation, love books, are community minded, and like a little physical activity, this is the volunteer opportunity for you!
06901.title: Become a Book Cart Champion During the School Year

06901.description: Protect our environment and the special world in which we live. Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned Connecticut citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Together we can protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more. You will: Meet with Congressional leaders. Write letters to the editors and op-eds. Meet with local media. Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions. We provide: Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers. Weekly skill building sessions. On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S. National conference and lobby week in D.C. Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world. Want to know more? Please join our weekly Introductory Conference Call. The next one is on Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. It is a live call, about an hour long, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. Please register for the call at this link so that we can follow up with you: https://citizensclimatelobby.org/join-weekly-intro-call/ We look forward to working with you!
06901.title: Sustainable Climate Environment Advocate Stamford CT

06901.description: This Stamford lady needs a volunteer driver for local trips to area medical offices while she waits for training with her new guide dog. Volunteer in your community with this high impact but easy way to make a huge difference. Requirements to be a great volunteer include: a desire to help others; a pleasant demeanor; a good reading/speaking voice; average reading skills; organizational or planning abilities; a good driving record; a clear criminal history; two references access to a car with proof of insurance; a minimum of $50/100k liability and $5,000 of property damage coverage.
06901.title: Driver or Bus Companion Needed for Stamford Lady and Her Guide Dog
06901.org: Department of Rehabilitation Services; Services for the Blind

06901.description: By providing childcare at either of our sites in Norwalk or Stamford, you will help the mothers who receive DVCC's services to be able to participate fully in support groups and counseling sessions, or to attend doctors' appointments, job interviews or just have a few moments to themselves. You must be 16 years of age or older and a comittment of 2 hours a week would be most welcomed. Before becoming a Certified Volunteer and being able to have direct client contact, you will be required to take our state certified 20-hour Educational Seminar, This is given twice a year, Spring and Fall.
06901.title: Child welfare Volunteers

06901.description: DVCC's PeaceWorks programs brings awareness and education to the schools in the seven towns that we serve. In our K-5 grade programs focus on anger management and conflict resolution. Our healthy families programs are presented to middle school and high school children. Our healthy relationship workshops are presented in 8th grade and high school. We also do various workshops on the topic of domestic violence to civic groups, professionals, and faith based communities. Volunteers help educators with Puppets, story telling, model positive behavior and get classroom materials ready for presentations.
06901.title: Preventive Education- PeaceWorks Volunteer

06901.description: A hotline volunteer works directly with victims of domestic violence by providing information and safety planning assistance. Training is required and will be provided by DVCC. Position also requires a 20 hour educational seminar mandated by the Coalition Against Domestic Violence.
06901.title: Hotline Volunteer

06901.description: Office helpers are asked to commit to a four hour shift helping with copying, filing, answering hotline and business phones, computer work, greeting clients, and processing mailings.
06901.title: Office Helpers

10466.description: Provide counseling and supportive services to high school students. Provide career and college counseling and advising to high school students. Paid Volunteer Position
10466.title: School Social Worker

10466.description: We are pleased to launch our New I'RAISE Event Committee! The Event Committee includes several leadership positions which will give interns experience in the areas of event planning, public relations, marketing and fundraising! Positions include Event Planner Supervisor Event Program Planner Event Public Relations Manager Event Fundraiser Specialist Event Committee Member Please sign up by completing the link below: https://goo.gl/forms/LcuvmOqnzauknnAi2
10466.title: Event Committee Planner

10466.description: R.A.I.N., Inc. is recruiting community members to be part of a new and very exciting Bronx Health Corps project aimed at educating Bronx seniors on asthma and how to manage their symptoms. The Bronx Health Corps is part of a Geriatric Workforce Enhancement Program grant designed to promote wellness and healthy aging among Bronx older adults. It is a partnership between the Hartford Institute for Geriatric Nursing (HIGN) at the NYU Rory Meyers College of Nursing, Montefiore Health System and R.A.I.N., Inc. Volunteers receive training by a registered nurse. This training will equip the volunteers to provide education sessions for older adults at a Bronx-based senior center or community site. The material will be engaging, interactive and fun! Prior knowledge of these topics is not required. Training for the volunteers is ongoing. The Bronx Health Corps project is a unique opportunity to help improve the health outcomes of Bronx older adults. Unfortunately, Bronx County is ranked last among all 62 counties in terms of population health. You can make a positive, perhaps even life-altering, impact in the lives of the Bronx’s older adults, by volunteering. Please take the first step and obtain an application via email. We look forward to hearing from you. Together we can make a difference!
10466.title: Teach Seniors About Managing Asthma Symptoms
10466.org: Regional Aid for Interim Needs, Inc. (R.A.I.N.)
