10022.description: We are working at the United Nations to strengthen the influence of civil society and the enforceability of international human rights and humanitarian law, as well as get the American public more involved with the work of the UN. This includes work with Agencies and NGO committees at the UN focused on NGO relations, women's issues, Palestine and disarmament, as well as the activist community in New York and across the USA.
10022.title: The United Nations:  This is Your World !!

10023.description: Volunteer opportunity - ACS Making Strides Against Breast Cancer/ Central Park Volunteers Needed! Are you looking to get more involved with your local community? Do you enjoy working with and meeting new people? Are you passionate about helping others and finishing the fight against cancer? If this sounds like you, the American Cancer Society needs you! The Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Walk of Central Park is one of the largest breast cancer awareness events in the nation. The money raised through the event helps save many lives by funding groundbreaking breast cancer research, providing free comprehensive information and support, and helping people take steps to reduce their risk of the disease or find it early when it’s most treatable. As the largest voluntary health organization in the country, we count on volunteers and volunteer driven organizations, agencies and companies to help make this event run smoothly and efficiently. The walk is on October 15th, 2017 located in Central Park and we need your help! Our volunteers help with important event details such as check in, water stations, information, and more. You’re there to help make the event truly special and to join, encourage, and support those in the fight against breast cancer! With just a few hours, you can help make a difference in countless lives and create a world with more birthdays! If interested, please contact our Event Manager Denise Solorzano, at Denise.Solorzano@cancer.org or by phone at 212-237-3813.
10023.title: Making Strides Against Breast Cancer-- Central Park Volunteer

10023.description: Generation 180 is dedicated to driving a cultural shift in energy awareness and advancing the transition to clean energy. The organization is looking for volunteers to support its clean energy campaigns.The Generation 180 volunteer teams will lead workshops that encourage community members to adopt clean energy solutions, support local schools in going solar, and encourage businesses to stop energy waste. Generation 180 is committed to empowering its volunteer teams with ongoing training and support to be effective in making positive changes in your community. Please visit www.generation180.org to learn more.
10023.title: Clean Energy Volunteer- New York, NY

10023.description: Are you fascinated by architecture? New York City? History? Are you inspired to fight for the preservation of New York's architectural legacy? Are you looking for a way to learn more about these subjects, while helping in the fight to protect the physical history and human scale which give New York its unique and beloved character? If so, we're looking for your help. Landmark West! is a preservation watchdog and advocacy group that has been fighting for the protection of architecture on Manhattan's Upper West Side for over 30 years. We are currently working to catalog all the landmarks in our historic districts, and we are looking for some dedicated volunteers to help out with compiling our online database. The job entails reading designation reports and entering information on buildings listed, along with photographs and map coordinates, into an online template, and then adding the newly created entries to our public database. Requisites: Must be comfortable using basic online tools. Coding experience is not needed, but prior experience working with website builders such as WordPress would be helpful. Hours: Flexible, an afternoon a week, perhaps, at a time that works with your schedule. Our office hours are 9 AM to 6 PM, Monday through Friday.
10023.title: Historic Architecture Data Entry

10023.description: Music on the Inside, Inc. (MOTI) Connects incarcerated youth and at-risk youth with seasoned musicians to offer learning opportunities, creative encouragement and inspiring role models through the rehabilitative power of music. www.musicontheinside.org MOTI seeks two driven, inspired, and energetic individuals for a development Internship positions and an experienced office manager to help with day to day operations, systems, follow-up and correspondence. The Development Interns will work with MOTI’s Founder and team to support the organization’s fundraising efforts in identifying new funding prospects; prospect outreach; special events, including planning for MOTI’s Benefits; data research, tracking, and collection, etc. He/she will play an essential role in helping to bring MOTI’s advocacy, leadership, and membership efforts to the next level by assisting the organization in scoping out new funding opportunities. The ideal candidates have interest in fundraising, as well as advocacy and grassroots movement building, is a motivated, self-starter who is effective in a fast-paced environment, and possesses a great sense of humor. With our bold and ambitious goal and unique theory of change through music and mentorships for incarcerated and at-risk youth, this is an exciting professional opportunity. The right candidates can have a significant impact on redefining rehabilitation in corrections and justice in America. Requirements: * Candidates must demonstrate interest in incarceration reform, effective rehabilitation through music, addressing racial disparities in the criminal system, and a belief in the power and efficacy of music for encouraging leadership and social change. * Development Interns are expected to commit to a minimum of 20 hours per week for the duration of the internship, as well as remote working capabilities (as needed). Development Interns must be willing to be on site at correctional facilities, meetings and events to support all of MOTI’s advocacy, leadership, membership, and development/fundraising efforts as needed. * Excellent writing skills is a must as he/she will be assisting with drafting emails, proposals and other relevant communications distributed both internally and externally. These are unpaid internships but can be credit-bearing and Music on the Inside, Inc. will work with academic institutions to ensure credit approval, if applicable. Please submit with your interest in applying the following: Your interest in criminal justice reform and advocacy; Why you want to intern at Music on the Inside, Inc; The strengths and experience you bring to the team; Your time availability for a minimum of 2-3 days; And what you are looking to experience? Only applicants selected for interviews will be contacted. Music on the Inside, Inc. (www.musicontheinside, inc.) is an equal opportunity/affirmative action employer. All qualified applicants will be considered for employment without unlawful discrimination based on race, color, creed, national origin, sex, age, disability, marital status, sexual orientation, military status, prior record of arrest or conviction, citizenship status, or curretn employment status. Music on the Inside values diverse experiences, including with regard to the justice system.
10023.title: Development and Administrative assistance for Music on the Inside, Inc.

10023.description: Your unique collection of life experiences can make a tremendous impact on the lives of young people new to America. By volunteering as a mentor with Table Wisdom you will have the chance to cultivate invaluable relationships as a mentor while helping foreign born students and young professionals practice their conversational English skills. It's as easy as signing up, getting paired, and starting a conversation. You and your mentee set the schedule and the student is expected to prepare topics for conversation. Our pairs talk about everything: from sports and culture to industry-specific skills and knowledge, what you discuss is up to you and your mentee. We do our best to pair people in similar disciplines so our mentees can learn from your career-specific experience, and you can learn more about what's new in your field. By having fun yet meaningful conversations you will help students build their confidence and fluency in English. All you need is the ability to video chat and the desire to meet someone new. Help a young foreign born person improve their quality of life in America. Join Table Wisdom: https://www.table-wisdom.org/join-us \"Although our lives are so different and perhaps distant, it is encouraging that there is so much that we share trying to be our best selves and making this a better world.\" -- Alan, mentor \"I feel so blessed to have met my excellent English language mentor. He always encourages me to speak out and taught me some idiomatic English which I didn't learn from a textbook.\" -- Zachary, mentee
10023.title: Share your experience! Mentor foreign born students and young professionals

07931.description: The Arc Foundation of Somerset County is seeking an intern for 3 to 4 hours a week who is interested in learning the day to day tasks within the fundraising and marketing arm of The Arc Foundation of Somerset County. Duties include: Learning/Working with a donor application program for entries and reporting Learning/Working with the creation and design of new/revised agency department brochures and website content Learning/Working and supporting the planning, organizing, and day to day functions that lead up to a spring 5K run and walk event on June 2, 2018. This includes ongoing marketing, sponsorship solicitation, community outreach, social media marketing, recruiting, and all on-site day of event operations. Learning/Working on Constant Contact, an online marketing program used for E-Newsletters Learning/Working on the Camp Jotoni Capital Campaign including assisting with outreach and marketing Website content and social media development for \"The Achievement Center\" at Raritan Valley Community College The hours needed for this internship will vary based on the individual's schedule, however, we are looking for a total of 3-4 hours per week Monday-Friday during business hours. If possible we would like the volunteer to attend the Walk/5K event on Saturday, June 2, 2018, at Duke Island Park in Bridgewater.
07931.title: Marketing/Fundraising/Event Planning Intern Wanted

06830.description: PLACEMENT PURPOSE OPEN TIME DAYS Flexible. Two shifts per month, on-call from your｠home, either during the day or evening; exact times vary. REQUIRED TRAINING Red Cross Orientation Disaster Cycle Services an Overview Client Assistance System Disaster Action Team Workshop On the job training working with experienced disaster responders
06830.title: Disaster Relief: MNYN: Disaster Action Team Responder in Training
06830.org: American Red Cross - Greater New York Region

06830.description: PLACEMENT PURPOSE The coordinator serves in an on-call capacity and coordinates the Red Cross's response to fires and other emergencies; serving as the direct line of communication with the Emergency Communications Center (ECC) and DAT members in the field; dispatching the volunteers that are on shift for response and providing remote support, coordinating lodging and activating Client Assistance Cards (CAC); making notification to other Red Cross activities as needed. This position typically does not physically respond to the disasters, but there are occasionally exceptions OPEN TIME DAYS Coordinators are expected to cover a minimum of one 12 hour on-call shift per week. ｠The maximum a Coordinator can work consecutively is 24 hours. ｠There are both day and night shifts available. ｠Sunday through Saturday. ｠Day shifts are 7:00AM-7:00PM; Night shifts are 7:00PM - 7:00AM REQUIRED TRAINING -DCS an Overview -Other classes as needed
06830.title: Leadership: (RP) Disaster Action Team On Call Coordinator
06830.org: American Red Cross - Greater New York Region

06830.description: PLACEMENT PURPOSE Mass Care Service Associates provide for the immediate emergency needs of those affected by disaster in affected areas.This occurs through the activities of Sheltering, Feeding, Bulk Distribution, and Safe and Well Linking. OPEN TIME DAYS Shifts vary depending on disaster.｠ Requires a strong on-going commitment. REQUIRED TRAINING Red Cross Orientation Disaster Services: An Overview Basic Food Safety (online, selfpaced) Shelter Fundamentals Mass Care Workshops Career path provided by department
06830.title: Dedicate your time to a world class Disaster organization!: MNYN: Mass Care Volunteer
06830.org: American Red Cross - Greater New York Region

06830.description: AARP FOUNDATION TAX-AIDE IS LOOKING FOR YOU! Are you looking for an incredible opportunity to help those in your own community? One that provides an opportunity to meet new people, learn new skills and help those in need? If so, AARP FOUNDATION TAX-AIDE is looking for you! We are the largest FREE volunteer -run tax preparation program in the nation with more than 35,000 volunteers serving more than 2.6 million taxpayers at more than 6000 sites nationally. Our incredible teams of volunteers are people just like you who give a few hours each week during the tax season to help low-moderate income taxpayers prepare and file their federal and state tax returns ensuring that they receive the tax credits and deductions they deserve! Right here in Connecticut alone last year our volunteers provided FREE tax return preparation to more than 30,000 residents at more than 95 sites throughout the state. This service alone saved CT taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars in tax preparation fees and returned more than $22 million in federal refunds and credits to our clients. We have a variety of positions from Greeters to Counselors and Electronic Return Originators just to name a few. Our sites operate weekdays during the tax season and while personal tax return preparation is helpful, training is provided. To learn more about our program or to register as a volunteer, please visit our website @ www.aarp.org/taxaide . Once your registration is received a volunteer in your area will contact you to discuss the program and answer any questions you may have. We look forward to hearing from you!
06830.title: Looking for a Volunteer Opportunity in Greenwich?  AARP Foundation Tax-Aide is looking for you!

06830.description: The Greenwich Department of Health is actively seeking to recruit both medical and non-medical public health volunteers in the community to assist during public health emergencies and related health programs. The Medical Reserve Corps program focuses on registering volunteers to staff mass dispensing clinics (e.g., dispensing antibiotics or vaccines) and to respond to threats ranging from pandemic influenza, bioterrorist attacks to severe storms such as super-storm Sandy. However, the MRC could be activated for a wide range of support services needed in the community, such as health fairs and seasonal influenza clinics
06830.title: Greenwich MRC Volunteer

06830.description: Volleyball coach needed for Fall! Volunteers can help our members learn the basics of basketball, hockey, lacrosse, swimming and many other sports. Evening and weekend opportunities starting this fall. Volunteer opportunities to coach in leagues as well.
06830.title: Build Character and Confidence through Sports

06830.description: We have an active and growing knitting club. Our amazing volunteers help students learn to knit fun and imaginative projects during the school year. We will need a few additional helpers after school. You don't need to be an expert knitter, but some experience is helpful.
06830.title: Fun with Knitting

06830.description: Help our members to acheive academic success this fall through different tutoring options 1) Help members complete homework at our drop in home work club - ideal for volunteers who need a more flexible schedule 2) Provide one one one tutoring in reading, math or other subject - work with one member through the year on a set schedule 3) Volunteers 21 and over are needed to help tutor in our teen room
06830.title: Support Academic Success

06830.description: Supermarketing for Seniors is recruiting volunteer shoppers to help frail, elderly, and home bound seniors who live in Greenwich CT with their weekly grocery shopping needs. Volunteers are needed to shop once a week. Volunteers must possess a valid drivers license and a car. This program helps our senior population remain independent and living in their own homes. Your help is greatly needed and appreciated. Our shoppers will spend a minimum of 2 hours a week shopping for seniors. We are also looking for volunteers during the winter months to do light snow shoveling for seniors.
06830.title: Supermarketing for Seniors
06830.org: Jewish Family Services of Greenwich-Supermarketing for Seniors

06831.description: THE ORGANIZATION: Abilis (ABLE-ISS) is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that provides services and supports for over 700 individuals with special needs and their families from birth through the life span. Abilis has been a leader in serving the special needs community in lower Fairfield County for 65 years and has a long-standing reputation for high quality care. REPORTS TO: Chief Operating Officer/Director of Human Resources HOURS: Flexible. Estimate a 20 hour/week commitment GENERAL RESPONSIBILITIES: Abilis is seeking a volunteer coordinator to act as a point person for volunteers throughout the organization. The Coordinator will design, plan and direct a volunteer program to augment the services of the regular staff. Oversee the recruiting, interviewing, hiring, training, and scheduling of volunteer workers. Ensures that volunteer project milestones/goals are met. KEY AREAS OF RESPONSIBILITY: Plan the volunteer program/service Develop and implement goals and objectives for the volunteer program which reflect the Abilis mission. Assess the need for volunteers to enhance program/service delivery Conduct ongoing evaluation of the programs and services delivered by volunteers and implement improvements as necessary Organize the volunteer program/service Develop and administer forms and records to document the volunteer activities Identify volunteer assignments that provide meaningful work for volunteers and write the volunteer position descriptions in consultation with staff as appropriate Engage volunteers Promote the volunteer program to gain community support of the volunteer program and the organization Develop and implement effective strategies to recruit the right volunteers with the right skills Develop and implement an intake and interview protocol for potential volunteers to ensure the best match between the skills, qualification, and interests of the volunteers and the needs of Abilis. Implement a screening process for potential volunteers according to accepted screening standards and practices Lead the volunteer program/service Train staff to work effectively and cooperatively with volunteers Orient volunteers to increase their understanding of Abilis, its clients, its services and the role and responsibilities of volunteers Ensure that volunteers are given appropriate training to be successful in their positions Ensure that volunteer check-in procedures are followed and records of volunteer hours are maintained according to established procedures Ensure that volunteers receive the appropriate level of supervision Establish and implement a process for evaluating the contribution of individual volunteers Conduct volunteer feedback program to track successes and identify problems so that relationships are maintained and system improvements are made Provide ongoing support and guidance for volunteers Act as a single point of contact for communications Plan and implement formal and informal volunteer recognition activities to recognize the contribution of volunteers to the organization Strives for growth in the volunteer program. Develops a plan to recruit new volunteers to Abilis and sets goals for that development. Prepare an annual report on the contribution of the volunteer program to the organization RELEVANT EXPERIENCE: Ideally, experience working with volunteers or volunteer organizations and/or active in community service activities and organizations this candidate will have some experience in managing volunteers, and/or some experience in working with special needs populations. Above all, we are seeking someone who is energetic, hardworking, and passionate about the people we serve. SKLLS AND CAPABILITIES : Must be able to demonstrate sensitivity to the issues intrinsic to managing and rewarding volunteer staff Demonstrated capability to effectively communicate orally and in writing. Ability to work well with a diverse group of staff and volunteers Ability to effectively manage a wide array of tasks, projects, and responsibilities Strong organization and planning skills essential. Demonstrated ability with team building. Ability to work productively in an unstructured environment. Proficient in basic computer applications, such as word processing, spreadsheets, database, and internet usage. Good record keeping skills. ************************* Please submit a resume thoughtful cover letter describing your experience, what you can uniquely bring to Abilis and what interests you about the position/organization to Eva Kramer at kramer@abilis.us.
06831.title: Coordinator of Volunteer Services (Volunteer Position)

06831.description: Abilis (ABLE-ISS) is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that provides services and supports for over 700 individuals with special needs and their families from birth through the life span. Abilis has been a leader in serving the special needs community in lower Fairfield County for 65 years and has a long-standing reputation for high quality care. We are seeking volunteers to help out in all areas, from residential services to recreational activities (including cooking class, music, and softball matches)! Schedules can be flexible and molded according to what your availability is. Experience working with and/or volunteering with special needs populations is a plus, but not required. Please reach out to Kramer@abilis.us with any questions or interests!
06831.title: Volunteer with Abilis

06831.description: Welcome to the ASD Climber Foundation! ASD stands for Autism Spectrum Disorders. We are working with a family in your area with a child on the autism spectrum. The family wants to train volunteers to help them run a home based social skills program called the Son-Rise Program. No experience necessary. Free training provided. Time commitment is 4 hours a week for 6 months or more. PLEASE READ: After completing the \"I want to help\" page, you will immediately receive an auto reply email with our Volunteer Profile. Please fill this out, and we will forward it directly to the family in your area that requires help. ***please add asdclimberfoundation@me.com to your safe list and check your junk mail if you do not see an immediate response in your inbox*** Thank you for your time!
06831.title: Greenwich, CT: Autism Volunteer

07936.description: STEM Mentors act as coaches for the purpose of inspiring, motivating, and educating the students in a science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) subject matter. S/he answers student questions about the professional work environment. Staying with the same group of students throughout the day, and throughout each of the three visits during the school year, s/he is an ambassador for sponsor corporations. The Mentors makes themselves available to answer questions about the career application of the laboratory techniques being used and insures safety of the students. HOURS - 8:30am to 3:00pm on days when students are present.
07936.title: STEM Mentors

07936.description: STEM Instructors for Students 2 Science (S2S) are subject matter experts who provide instruction and guidance to students who visit the organization's $4 million laboratory in East Hanover where the students are able to conduct scientific experiments. The STEM Instructor provides information in a clear and concise manner, encouraging participation, helping to reduce the intimidation often associated with laboratory work, and shares his/her interest and/or passion for science. The Instructor strives to generate confidence and enthusiasm for the scientific technique being used while insuring the safety of participants. There are also Virtual lab opportunities for scientists serving as Instructors. HOURS-- 8:30AM to 3:00PM on days when students are present If you are interested, please apply at http://www.students2science.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=86&Itemid=251 or contact S2S at (973) 947-4880. To learn more about S2S, see our About Us video at https://students2science.wistia.com/medias/hbxylzpw5o. If you have additional questions, please email us at volunteers@students2science.org.
07936.title: STEM Instructors

07936.description: The STEM Lab Assistants assist students in following procedures; performing calculations, using instrumentation, and offers recommendations to instructor (after students have completed the program) for modifying experimental procedures. Lab Assistants insure safety of the students by monitoring student activities. HOURS-- 8:30AM to 3:00PM on days when students are present If you are interested, please apply on www.students2science.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=86&Itemid=251. If you have questions, please email us at volunteers@students2science.org. To learn more about S2S, click here: https://students2science.wistia.com/medias/hbxylzpw5o.
07936.title: STEM Lab Assistants/Mentors

11220.description: Exciting opportunity to work in a fast paced hospital marketing environment.Duties are heavily clerical in nature with the need for imagination, creativity and dedication.Be involved in postings, assist with VIP mailing, facilitate poster design, laminating. Maintain internalsupply of maketing materials and signs. Assist with photo shoots, and other marketing activities as assigned.
11220.title: Marketing/External Affairs Intern ( Unpaid)

11220.description: This specific Volunteer role is for families with children aged, 14 + who would like to volunteer as a family. There are opportunities to volunteer with recuperating patients and senior residents, playing Bingo, assisting residents in learning how to manage computers, and other electronic devices and friendly visiting. A visit to patients and residents without close family can provide comfort and a feeling of self worth. Families who volunteer together can provide a sense of belonging to patients and long-term residents while sharing a positive family experience.
11220.title: Friendly Family Visit Project

11220.description: Join our Visit Corps... share companionship with an elderly resident in our extended care facility, provide a smiling face for a patient in the hospital, share your time reading with and for a patient who would truly appreciate a warm, friendly face.
11220.title: Friendly Visitor

11220.description: Share your (trained) dog 's unconditional love with patients on Patient Care floors. You and your dog can become trained volunteers and provide a wonderful service of visiting our patients and families during their stay in the hospital. You can become a bona fide volunteer and your dog ( trained through the Good Dog Foundation) can become a wonderful companion and asset in bringing good cheer and unconditional affection in designated patient care floors.
11220.title: Got an Hour? - Share your Pet Dog with patients

11220.description: Provide a warm welcome to patients and families. Demonstrate professionalism, compassion and problem-solving. Assist same - day surgery patients and families navigate electronic tracking system. Provide information and escort patients and families to appropriate areas. Demonstrate the highest customer service experience for patients and families. Able to work with a diverse population including all age groups, ethnicities and genders. Assist in communication between the OR staff,Ambulatory Surgery Liaison and patients/families.
11220.title: Ambulatory Surgery Ambassador

11220.description: The NYU Lutheran ~ Super Sprowtz program is an engaging, fun way to teach kids and their families about healthy eating. The Super Sprowtz Volunteer will read stories, use puppets, coloring pages and other interactive material to engage and inform kids about vegetables with super powers and healthy eating as they wait in the Emergency Room and Family Health Clinics. Make a difference in a child's life, help them form good eating habits now, and keep a community healthy.
11220.title: Brighten a Child's Hospital visit - Be a Super Sprowtz Volunteer

11220.description: Essential Duties and Responsibilities: Provide a warm welcome to patients, families and visitors. Provide information and escort person(s) to their destination. Work closely with Information Desk Receptionist/volunteers and Security as needed to assist person(s) in need. Provide wheel chair service as needed. Contact appropriate LMC staff member (i.e., VP Development, DVS, Patient Advocate) if needed for assistance, clarification or encounter of an unusual circumstance.
11220.title: Hospital Ambassador- Bring a smile to patients and families

11220.description: Join a group of dedicated clinical and non-clinical professionals who provide excellent patient and family care to a diverse population. As a specially chosen LMC volunteer in the Emergency Room, you will: Escort visitors within the ED Provide Friendly Visiting to patients and vistor Assist clinical staff as directed
11220.title: Action packed - Emergency Room Volunteer

11220.description: Patient assistance volunteers have indirect contact with patients on medical and surgical units. They assist staff with bed making, running errands, visiting patients, patient escort, setting up meal trays, checking on call lights, and some general clerical work. Volunteers become part of the patient service team. The assignment offers opportunities to work with patients,families and professional staff. There is an opportunity to learn first hand about hospital systems and the many roles in the healthcare field.
11220.title: Volunteer on Patient Care Units

11212.description: We are an exciting start-up agency who are seeking dynamic individuals who have a passion for serving, and teaching, women, children. Using our own curriculum, the volunteer would be responsible for facilitating weekly workshops with women on various topics from hygiene, finances, and more. Rotate between a group of other volunteers to teach one day or evening a week, for ninety minutes for the Fall and Spring semesters. Please check out our website to learn more about our wonderful organization.
11212.title: Volunteers Needed-Weekly Life Skills Workshops

11212.description: What is Young Women Rock!? Young Women Rock! is dedicated to strengthening the lives and communities of young women in under-served neighborhoods through a sustainable curriculum-based, group and one-on-one mentorship program. The mentorship program provides young women with the resources and support necessary to make positive life choices and create community change. Young Women Rock! encourages and empowers young women to make informed and healthy decisions about their relationships, sexual health, future options, and broader women’s issues. To learn more about the program, please view our feature on MSNBC. How does Young Women Rock! work? Pairing group-based mentoring with one-on-one mentor/mentee relationships, Young Women Rock! helps young women build self-esteem and awareness to make healthy choices as they mature. Each Saturday, a group of mentors lead interactive, fun and educational sessions on issues that are important to young women. We invite guest speakers and lead dynamic workshops, as well as take the young women on a cultural outing once a month. Important Details: Where does Young Women Rock! meet? TBA, Brownsville, Brooklyn, NY (Sutter stop on the L train; Junius stop on the 3 train) When does Young Women Rock! meet? Saturdays from 1:00PM-3:30PM. Consistent attendance is essential. It is important that we are a stable, reliable and supportive part of their lives. How long does Young Women Rock! last? One academic year (starting Saturday, September 30, 2017); You must be able to make this commitment How to apply: Submit your application by September 10, 2017. You will be required to attend a training session and undergo a background check. Application: http://womenworldwideinitiative.org/mentorship-program/apply/
11212.title: Young Women Rock! Mentor - Brooklyn

11212.description: ProjectArt is in desperate need of anyone who is available over the next three weeks (now- September 1st) to assemble one cabinet in each of ProjectArt's 10 libraries! These cabinets will house each program's art supplies and will be a small but essential aspect of the free art classes we offer to youth. The cabinets are super simple to put together and just require a screw driver and about two pairs of hands. Here is a video for what assembly would look like: youtube.com/watch?v=y_WVyaFuvGw. I would say about two volunteers per library is all we would need to put cabinets together! In general if anyone is available during weekdays or Saturdays between 10am and 6:30pm, we could really use some help. Some libraries are open till 8pm depending on the day. Please let me know if any of you are available this month!
11212.title: Assemble a Cabinet @ Stone Avenue Brooklyn Public Library

11212.description: ABOUT Great opportunity for a creative, ambitious college student or recent graduate looking to gain professional experience in all aspects of the event planning industry. Must be personable, detail-oriented, and comfortable working in a fast-paced work environment. STATUS Hours are flexible, but we prefer to set a definitive schedule with a minimum commitment of 15-20 hours per week. Can work virtually REPORTS TO Event Coordinator and or Board ACADEMIC CREDIT If intern wishes to receive academic credit for the internship, it will be the intern’s responsibility to make arrangements with his or her school. BkMSCC will provide the necessary job description and performance review upon request. POSITION SUMMARY The Intern serves as a key member of the Brooklyn Multi-Service Community Center, Corp. (BkMSCC) team. Upon completion of the internship, candidates leave with a foundation of knowledge for producing successful events and ideally have the tools with which to tackle producing an event of their own. Duties will include but are not limited to the following: Assist in all aspects of event coordination including planning, design, marketing, fundraising, and sponsorship Perform responsibilities as assigned at BkMSCC events (some evenings and weekends necessary) Meeting preparation: scheduling and coordination of appropriate materials for client and new business meetings Research new event spaces, restaurants, and resources related to our industry Office reception: answering phones, receiving deliveries, ordering supplies Mailings and list management: compiling and updating mailing lists, tracking RSVPs for events, and coordinating large mailings Being creative, collaborative, and having fun! Qualifications: Good writing and communication skills Strong computer skills including Microsoft Word, Excel, and PowerPoint Strong organizational skills and exceptional attention to detail Internet research Ability to handle multiple tasks Availability to work occasional evenings and weekends Interest in pop culture, food, arts, travel, health and wellness, and nonprofit fundraising Required education: High school or equivalent
11212.title: Event Planner

11212.description: The Volunteer Services Department at the Brookdale Hospital and Medical Center is seeking volunteers to participate in their Volunteer Child Life Program. The volunteers will assist the Child Life Specialist in providing a safe and developmentally appropriate environment for the children in the hospital. Volunteers are trained by a certified Child Life Speacialist in child development and hospital policies so they feel confident working with the children. Child Life volunteers work directly with the children and their families by bringing toys, games, crafts, movies, music or other resources to the children's room. Volunteers also bring childen to the playroom where they can play games and hold arts and crafts activities. We are seeking compassionate, caring individuals who enjoy working with children.
11212.title: Child Life Volunteer
11212.org: THE BROOKDALE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENT

11212.description: Surgical Advocate Volunteers provide an important link for communication and support to family members of surgical patients to obtain non-medical information regarding the status of the patient.
11212.title: Surgical Advocate Volunteer
11212.org: THE BROOKDALE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENT

11212.description: Volunteer Greeters are trained to provide a warm and welcoming atmosphere for patients and visitors at The Brookdale University Hospital and Medicla Center, and will provide diretion to locations throughout the hospital. Greeters work collaboratively with hopsital and medical staff to help maintain our commitment to ALWAYS provide the highest personalized quality care and service excellence.
11212.title: GREETER PROGRAM
11212.org: THE BROOKDALE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENT

11212.description: Volunteers provide health literacy assistance and education to our outpatient population in an effort to teach basic health literacy skills to enable compliance with appropriate understanding of medication labels, assistance with managing multiple medications and maintaining a medical journal.
11212.title: Pharmacy Partners Volunteer Program
11212.org: THE BROOKDALE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENT

11212.description: The purpose of this volunteer program is provide assistance to patients being treated in the Emergency Department, their family members/escorts. Volunteers will interact with family members/escorts of those patients keeping them appraised of the patients' progress. Volunteers will provide only non-medical information. Other duties will include: * Escorting patients and or family members to treatment areas. *Providing general information to persons waiting in the Emergency Department, * Assisting medical staff with patients as needed.
11212.title: EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT CARING LINKS PROGRAM
11212.org: THE BROOKDALE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENT

11212.description: A hospital stay for a child can be a lonely, frightening experience. Reading books and telling stories can brighten a young persons hospital stay and stimulate the imagination. Volunteer are needed to read to pediatric patients at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. You must be 18 years of age, and have a good command of the English language. Experience with children is highly preferred. Volunteers are required to commit to a minimum two hour shift one day per week and a total of 150 hours. To find out more about our reading program, or to inquire about other exciting volunteer opportunities, please call the Volunteer Services Department at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center at (718) 240-5277between 9:00am- 5:30pm, Monday through Friday.
11212.title: Bedtime Storybook Reader
11212.org: THE BROOKDALE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENT

11212.description: Several volunteer opportunities exist in the hospital and/or nursing home. These include: Clerical, Surgical Advocate, Emergency Room, Pediatric Storybook Reading, Elderly Friendly Visiting, Pastoral Care, Book Cart, Recreation Therapy, plus more..
11212.title: VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNTITIES
11212.org: THE BROOKDALE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENT

11213.description: Work with Adult Literacy Students at one of the five Brooklyn Public Library Learning Centers. Help them reach their personal goals. Lead reading and writing activities for small groups of adult learners who read below the fifth grade level. Assist them in using technology. We provide a 20 hour Volunteer Tutor Training where you will learn the BPL’s Literacy Program’s philosophy, how to use the library’s resources for instruction, and how to create effective lesson plans. Professional staff will encourage your development in this richly rewarding field. Volunteers must have a high school diploma or equivalent and a love of reading and writing. Volunteers are asked for a one year commitment to tutoring either 2 - 2 hours sessions, or 1 - 3-hour session per week. To learn more about the Brooklyn Public Library Learning Centers, please visit the BPL website at http://www.bklynibrary.org. To register to attend a Volunteer Information Session, please click here.
11213.title: Volunteer Literacy Tutor Information Session
11213.org: The Learning Centers @ Brooklyn Public Library

11213.description: Fiver Children's Foundation is seeking a motivated youth Co-Facilitator in Brooklyn to join the Fiver team and support its mission of empowering the youth through character cultivation year round. Every month, Fiver Children's Foundation hosts Fiver Club, a program where Fiver participants learn character building traits that align with Fiver's three pathways to success: Education and Careers, Service and Leadership, and Healthy Life Choices. Fiver's Youth Co-Facilitator will assist Fiver's Program Supervisor at Fiver Clubs as a support staff by facilitating certain curriculum pieces and handling behavior management. This position is responsible for creating a safe and productive environment, ensuring a high level of program quality, and working to establish a positive relationship with Fiver participants. Fiver's Youth Co-Facilitator will review curriculum with Fiver Program Supervisor prior to the dates of Fiver Club. Responsibilities include, but are not limited to Leading and assisting with curriculum activities and games with Fiver participants that align with Fiver's three pathways to success Supporting the Fiver Program Supervisor Monitoring participants behavior Adequately observing participants activities and enforcing safety regulations and program expectations Qualifications Experience working with the youth, preferably 5th through 8th grade Flexibility Creativity Behavior management and conflict resolution skills Verbal communication skills Leadership and facilitation skills Must be willing to commit to monthly Fiver Clubs on the dates listed below Dates for Fiver Club in Brooklyn, St. Johns Recreation Center Wednesday, January 24th at 4pm - 6pm Wednesday, February 28th at 4pm - 6pm Wednesday, March 21st at 4pm - 6pm Wednesday, April 25th at 4pm - 6pm
11213.title: Youth Co-Facilitator in Brooklyn, St. Johns Recreation Center

11213.description: Do you live or work in Crown Heights? We are looking for kind, patient, firendly volunteers who are interested in getting to know their frail and/or hombound older neighbors. Become a Friendly Visitor and spend a few hours a week walking and/or visiting with an isolated older neighbor who will benefit from your company!
11213.title: Crown Heights needs Friendly Visitors!

11210.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
11210.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS K315, Brooklyn)

11210.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a part-time 14-hours per week, unpaid telecommuting internship. The internship is 4-months and responsible for leading public and political outreach in the state and district assigned to. Key Responsibilities: - Must be available Mondays 4:30-6:00 PM PST for The Borgen Project’s national conference call. - Meet with members of Congress and/or Congressional staffers in your State and District. - Represent The Borgen Project at various business, political and community events. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Mobilize individuals to contact their members of Congress in support of key poverty-reduction legislation. - As needed, speak to groups, classes and organizations. - Write letters of support for key programs to political leaders, media and other groups. Qualifications: - Outstanding writing skills. - Self-starter who can produce great results with limited supervision. - Strong oral communication skills and ability to lead meetings and give speeches.
11210.title: Political Affairs Internship

11210.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and set their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Interview sources and research topics in-depth. - Write one well-researched article per week. - Communicate with editors and supervisors. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong journalism writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing for newspapers is helpful, but not required.
11210.title: Journalism Internship

11210.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and pick their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Write one article per week. - Research topics. - Assist with advocacy efforts. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong research and writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing SEO friendly content is helpful, but not required.
11210.title: Writer Internship

11210.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. The Borgen Project is hiring an HR Intern who will work remotely. This human resources role will focus on national recruitment and updating job postings. Key Responsibilities: - Update job postings (80% of internship). - Inform groups and classes of openings. - Take on various tasks as needed. - Everyone who is part of the organization assists the team with fundraising, 25-hours of this position is dedicated to creating and implementing a personal fundraising campaign. - Assist with advocacy efforts. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The HR internship is 12-hours per week for 12-weeks.
11210.title: HR Internship

11210.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. The Borgen Project is hiring a Public Relations/Marketing Intern who will work remotely. This public relations intern will be involved in a variety of aspects of marketing and communications. Key Responsibilities: - Create a branding campaign. - Conduct an informal focus group and gather feedback for market research. - Pitch story ideas to print, broadcast and digital media. - Create and implement a fundraising strategy. - Plan, market and present at an informational meeting. - Utilize social media and develop strategies for web-based messaging. - Assist with The Borgen Project's advocacy efforts. - Take on assignments as needed. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The internship is 12-hours per week for 12-weeks. Must meet weekly deadlines.
11210.title: Public Relations/Marketing Internship

11210.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. You don’t need to be a lobbyist to help influence foreign policy. As a Regional Director, you’ll serve as a Borgen Project Ambassador in your city - mobilizing your friends, family and colleagues to contact Congress in support of key poverty reduction legislation. This is an unpaid, volunteer position. Key Responsibilities: - Attend one (30-60 minute) national conference call per month: 5PM PDT 6PM MDT 7PM CDT 8PM EDT - Meet with local congressional leaders and lobby for legislation that improves living conditions for the world’s poor. - Mobilize people in your community to contact their congressional leaders to support poverty reduction legislation. - Manage and implement fundraising campaigns. - Build a network of people engaged in the cause. - Serve as The Borgen Project’s ambassador in your city. Qualifications: - Basic understanding of U.S. Politics and international development. - Highly organized with the ability to prioritize multiple functions and tasks while managing their work time efficiently. - Strong team player that loves to bring new ideas to the table. - Ability to demonstrate frequent independent judgment with decisiveness. - Excellent overall communication skills: oral, written, presentation.
11210.title: Regional Director

11210.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. This is a great entry-level volunteer position for someone looking to be part of The Borgen Project. Advocates can operate from anywhere in the U.S. This is an unpaid, volunteer position. Key Responsibilities: - Attend one (30-60 minute) national conference call per month: 5PM PDT 6PM MDT 7PM CDT 8PM EDT - Serve as an ambassador for the world’s poor. Build awareness of the issues and ways people can help. - Manage and implement fundraising campaigns. - Represent The Borgen Project in your city - attend events and engage people in the cause. - Contact congressional leaders in support of key poverty-reduction programs. Qualifications: - Excellent overall communication skills: oral, written, presentation. - Ability to self-manage and prioritize assignments.
11210.title: Advocate

11211.description: Do you want to: Feel valued as a skilled professional engaged in building a critical, philanthropic arm of a social justice organization? Change lives by expanding the organization’s capacity to serve its clients and achieve justice? Gain experience and contacts in New York City’s legal services community? Become a respected and integral member of a team? If you answered yes, then bring your skills and interest to Brooklyn A to help grow its development and communications department! Established in 1968, Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation A (Brooklyn A) advances social and economic justice and community empowerment through innovative, collaborative, neighborhood-based legal representation and advocacy. We assist individuals, families, community-based organizations, and coalitions in sustaining and developing vibrant, healthy communities. The Development and Communications Volunteer will work as a part of the Development and Communications Team and will assist in executing the annual Development Plan. This is an excellent opportunity to utilize and grow your skills in fundraising, communications and non-profit management. This position is ideal for anyone, particularly recent college graduates, wishing to gain valuable professional experience and learn more about nonprofit development and communications. You don’t need a substantial background in the field, just be excited about our work and eager to learn! Responsibilities of the Development and Communications Volunteer Develop resources to retain existing donors, recapture lapsed donors, cultivate new donors, and increase gift size. Help develop and execute Brooklyn A’s development and communications plan including, but not limited to, generating online content that engages audience segments and leads to measurable results Support the grant proposal development and submission process-ensuring that proposals, reports and other documents are well written, strategic, and submitted on schedule. Assist in creating and executing a strategy for a large, sustained base of individual giving. Who Should Apply? Anyone with: Experience fundraising for local affinity groups, or an interest in learning about them Strong interpersonal communication skills The ability to work independently and as a team player Strong writing and organization skills, as well as creativity The ability to multitask, handling logistics, and following through on multiple projects simultaneously Microsoft Office skills including Word, Excel, and PowerPoint A desire to gain direct experience in and learn more about the nonprofit world! We strongly encourage people of color, of diverse gender identities, women, and LGBT persons to apply.
11211.title: Development & Communications Volunteer

11211.description: Riseboro Community Partnership is seeking fun, talkative and innovative volunteer who is interested in spending one hour, one day a week with one of our homebound senior citizen. We have a large population of Polish speaking clients who need a volunteer. We are currently looking for a Polish speaking volunteer for one of our seniors in Williamsburg. Our senior citizens are unable to go out into the community and are looking for a companion to laugh with, talk to, watch television with, paint or draw with and enjoy their time with! We ask that our volunteers commit to a minimum of 6 months with our seniors! This is a mutually rewarding friendship, where you're able to learn about the seniors in your neighborhoods, their art styles, interests and the changes that have occurred to the community over the years! We serve a diverse group of elderly and seek people of all backgrounds and ages (18 and up) to join us in helping them feel more connected to their communities. This Friendly Visiting Program is funded by The NYC Department for the Aging.
11211.title: Polish Speaking volunteer needed for Senior Citizen in Williamsburg
11211.org: RIDGEWOOD BUSHWICK SENIOR CITIZENS COUNCIL INC

11211.description: We are looking for a volunteer chef or someone who really enjoys cooking, to teach a small group of 10 people to prepare healthy low cost meals to individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Time commitment: Once a week or 2 or 3 times a month depending upon your availability. You will cook at an industrial Kitchen located in Williamsburg Brooklyn.
11211.title: Volunteer Chef to prepare healthy, low cost meals

11211.description: Purpose Regular exercise is an essential part of a healthy lifestyle. Lead a weekly zumba class for seniors to help keep them in shape. Responsibilities * Lead a group of seniors in a weekly zumba class * Create routines suitable for individuals with varied physical abilities * Communicate effectively and courteously with JASA seniors and staff Skills * Relevant exercise certification * Experience leading seniors in exercises * Experience with group exercise classes * Patience and sense of humor * Comfortable leading a group of varying skill levels Other * Flexible scheduling is available with a minimum commitment of one day a week * Ongoing opportunity * Maintain professional behavior at all times and adhere to JASA’s volunteer policies About JASA Founded in 1968, JASA's mission is to sustain and enrich the lives of the aging in the New York metropolitan area so that they can remain in the community with dignity and autonomy. JASA is one of New York's largest and most trusted agencies serving older adults in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, and Queens.
11211.title: Zumba Instructor - JASA Cooper Park Senior Center

11211.description: Time's Up! is a 27-year-old grassroots non-profit environmental organization located in New York City. Time's Up! organizes hundreds of educational workshops, events, and campaigns to promote environmental sustainability. We are currently seeking an Assistant to the Director Intern. Applicants must be flexible, computer savy, and fluent in English, with excellent writing, proofreading, and organizational skills.The position involves working in several different locations in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn, assisting the director in a variety of activities, including setting up events, managing spaces, organizing committees and meetings, and communicating with other organizations and volunteers. Commitment is approximately 15-20 hours per week (flexible hours). Time's Up! has a unique structure in that it is operated 100% by volunteers and has an incredible track record of accomplishment. This is an excellent opportunity to learn how a grassroots organization can effect substantial change. Please see our website at: http://times-up.org/
11211.title: INTERN- Time's Up! Assistant to the Director

11211.description: Time's Up! is a 27-year-old nonprofit environmental organization located in downtown New York City and Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Time's Up! is currently seeking a Volunteer Coordinator. This position involves overseeing and updating our volunteer database and identifying/recruiting prospective qualified volunteersto fill open volunteer positions. This position requires excellent organizational, communication, and computer skills. Experience with Gmail and FileMaker Pro or other database experience is preferred. The Volunteer Coordinator may also help with designing and implementing HR policies. Check out our website http://www.times-up.org
11211.title: Time's Up! - Volunteer Coordinator

11216.description: Calling all RUNNERS... interested in entering the 2018 TCS NYC Marathon but were not chosen in the lottery? You still can! Children of Promise, NYC (CPNYC), a nonprofit that embraces and empowers children of incarcerated parents, has slots for marathon runners on our 10-person team. To learn more about the benefits of running with Team CPNYC, which includes guaranteed entry into the race, please visit: https://www.cpnyc.org/marathon Run for a reason and raise awareness for a population of children who have an incarcerated parent! ABOUT CPNYC CPNYC is a community-based organization in Brooklyn working to ensure children left behind by prisoners are empowered to break the cycle of intergenerational incarceration and imagine futures bigger and brighter than their current circumstances. All funds raised will go directly toward program support and much needed therapeutic supplies and interventions.
11216.title: Run the 2018 TCS NYC Marathon!

11216.description: If You Have Completed/ Are Currenlty Working Towards Completing Your Beauty School Requirements And Want To Gain Experience In A Real Salon Under The Supervision Of The Top New York State Licensed Beauticians This Opportunity Is For You. We Are Seeking Nail Techs As Well.
11216.title: Hair Stylist & Nail Technicians

11216.description: Computer Science Program Instructor Needed! Digital Girl, Inc. is a non-profit organization dedicated to empowering inner-city youth to pursue careers in STEM disciplines. We are looking for a Program Instructor to lead and teach students in computer science. Instructor will review curriculum, manage classroom, supervise teaching assistants, teach children and prep for class. Instructors must have experience in technical field, experience working with children preferred. Patience, professionalism, good oral and written communication skills necessary. Time commitment is 3 hours, one day a week for 10-15 week session. Course material and training provided.
11216.title: Love Tech? Love Kids? Become The Change With Us!

11216.description: Children of Promise, NYC (CPNYC) seeks additional members for the Executive Board of Trustees to increase the capacity of its Board of Directors and act responsibly as a steward of the organization’s mission to embrace the children of incarcerated parents and empower them to break the cycle of intergenerational involvement in the criminal justice system. This is a special opportunity to help shape the course of a nonprofit organization management and fund development Children of Promise, NYC offers an innovative and unique after-school program and summer day camp, the only one of its kind in New York City, specifically designed to meet the needs, interests and concerns of children left behind by parents serving time in prison. We are looking for Executive Board of Trustee members who can: Raise awareness and act as an ambassador for CPNYC Create partnerships with various respected businesses/individuals Engage with the community Role and Responsibility: Host at least one small \"Friendraiser\" event consisting of 5-10 contacts that you would like to introduce to the agency Contribute a Give/Get of $5,000 annually Arrange agency site visits and meetings with Founder and President for at least two (2) prospective supporters In addition to the above responsibilities, CPNYC seeks board members who: Act as an ambassador for the organization, interpreting its mission and values to the community, professional and personal networks Attend 85% of the Board meetings, committee meetings and organization’s special events Make a meaningful personal financial contribution Stay up-to-date with the status of the program and it’s support offerings Are active participants in policy-making discussions, stay informed of best practices Send letter of interest and CV/Resume to President & Founder, Sharon Content, at scontent@cpnyc.org
11216.title: Seeking Active and Engaged Executive Board Members

11216.description: Food Not Bombs Mission Statement:Food Not Bombs recovers and shares free vegan or vegetarian food with the public without restriction in over 1,000 cities around the world to protest war, poverty and the destruction of the environment. Each group is independent and invites everyone to participate in making decisions for their local chapter using the consensus process. Food Not Bombs is dedicated to taking nonviolent direct action to change society so no one is forced to stand in line to eat at a soup kitchen expressing a commitment to the fact that food is a right and not a privilege. With over a billion people going hungry each day how can we spend another dollar on war? Hello Neighbor,I'm a volunteer with Long Island Food Not Bombs (LIFNB.com).We have Free Food Shares (Free Food, Clothing, Books, Baby Items, Household Items, Art, etc.) throughout Long Island and Brooklyn. Depends what donations we get from stores, churches, neighbors and volunteers. Usually there are fruits, vegetables, milk, dairy, bread, cakes, pies, canned and dry goods, pet food, etc. We also have clothes, household & baby items, books, art, etc. depending what is brought to the Food Shares that day.Ask for Volunteer Jon or Vincent if you have something to share. Say hello for me. Thank you, Volunteer Dennis A new release video: We start at 13:55: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fixP0UR_G_UCraigslist Post:Free \"Long Island Food Not Bombs\" Food SharesEvery Sunday at 2 PM, West Columbia Street & Station Plaza, Hempstead, NY 11550Every Tuesday at 7 PM, East 6th Street & Fairground Avenue, Huntington NY 11746Every Thursday at 7 PM, Horseblock Road & Woodycrest Drive, Farmingville, NY 11738Every Saturday at 12 PM, noon, 1556 Straight Path, Wyandanch, NY 11798Every Saturday at 3 PM, Lafayette Ave & Marcy Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11216All outdoors. Rain or Shine. No umbrellas or strollers by tables.Come Share With Your Community.Free Food, Clothing, Books, Baby Items, Household Items, Art, etc.Whatever is brought by our Volunteers, You (if you can) and Your Neighbors in Your Community.A Community is its Neighbors, not the towns they are in.Get there a few minutes before start time. Help us unload our Volunteers vehicles and set up tables.Bring empty bags, food, clothing, household items, baby items, books, etc to \"Share with Your Community\".See Volunteers if you do bring items to Share, or you want to volunteer to hand food and items out. Say hello for me, Dennis. Nothing to bring? Then bring yourselves.We'll help you get food and items you need. You don't need to bring any type of papers or ID to our Food Shares.Everyone is welcome to get Free Food, Clothing, Household Items, Baby Items, Books, Art, etc. Depends what is brought by our volunteers and other neighbors to share.We average 8,000 pounds of food and merchandise each Food Share.Just please be polite with your neighbors when we Share.We will not tolerate any type of racial slurs or bigotry.Please thank and help our Volunteers by taking recyclable cardboard (boxes to take home your food and items). Put out on your recycle day for pick up.More info go to our website: LIFNB.com Start Sharing:1) Pass this on to family, friends and neighbors in your community. 2) Copy flyers at LIFNB.com or this Craigslist post. Hand them out. Schools, Libraries, Senior Centers, Churches, Stores, etc.3) Maybe you are an owner, manager or employee of a store, supermarket, distributor, wholesaler, farm, or manufacturer. Do you have soon to be expired food, drinks and/or merchandise you will be throwing out?Help us help you save money. Less carting fees. Great Community Relations.Call the Hotline (631) 223-4370 - 10 AM - 2 PM.4) Next time you are in a store where you shop. Ask the owner or manager if they would like to donate soon to be expired food, drinks and/or merchandise they will be throwing out shortly. We'll pick up and they save money on carting fees and help the community. Give our Hotline Number (631) 223-4370 - 10 AM - 2 PM.5) Share on Facebook:\"Friend\" - Li FNB\"Like\" - Long Island Food Not Bombs6) Become one of our volunteers. Come and join us.No Food Shares in your area, volunteers will help you start one.We are not affiliated with any religion, church or political party. Community churches do donate food and items to our Food Shares.\"Long Island Food Not Bombs\" is the largest \"Food Not Bombs\" in the World.We do all this with no government funding, all volunteers. Volunteer to help us obtain funding.We are always in need of Plastic Folding Tables for our Food Shares. Donate when you can at: http://www.LIFNB.comThank you, Volunteer Dennis Peace

11216.description: Become a Volunteer Children of Promise, NYC (CPNYC) is a Brooklyn based non-profit organization committed to embracing and empowering the lives of children of incarcerated parents to break the cycle of intergenerational involvement in the criminal justice system. Volunteers contribute skills, time, knowledge, perspective and personal connections towards the advancement of CPNYC. Your support as a volunteer s is vital to the organization's growth and health. BECOME A MENTOR Mentor an individual child - mentoring works! Studies show that students who have a mentor are 52% less likely to skip school and 46% less likely to start using illegal drugs. FUNDRAISING Host an event Committee participation Volunteer at an event DIRECT SERVICES Assist with Art Classes Assist with Computer Classes Assist with Gym Classes Assist with Creative Movement Classes Assist with Dance Classes Assist with Homework Assist with Mental Health Services Assist with Library Services
11216.title: Seeking Volunteers & Mentors for Children of Promise, NYC

11217.description: READ 718 is looking for volunteer literacy tutors for our Winter cycle (January 8-March 22, 2018). Volunteers must attend an orientation and one training session. READ 718 is a non-profit literacy center that provides afterschool tutoring and literacy workshops to low-income students in grades 3-8. We are looking for dedicated, reliable, caring, positive people who are committed to working with a child twice a week for 10 weeks (January 8-March 22), excluding Public School vacation dates. Tutors will be provided with easy-to-follow lesson plans for each session, and will have access to reading specialists for questions and guidance. Children who are behind in reading after grade 3 and do not receive the targeted instruction that they need simply fall further and further behind. READ 718 aims to provide students with high quality, supplementary instruction to bridge the gap between students who are struggling and their grade level peers. If you are interested in being a volunteer tutor, please visit our site and complete application at: http://read718.org/volunteer-application/
11217.title: Volunteer Literacy Tutor

11217.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

11217.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.
